text:
I know I'm just another in a long line of reviewers, but I enjoyed this recipe just as much as everyone else! I didn't read through all the reviews, but from most of them I gathered modifications, which added up to a winning recipe!
- I only used 1/4 cup of brown sugar.
- I added 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce to the ketchup/brown sugar mix.
- I used 1/2 cup of milk and 1 egg.
- I added 2 cloves of garlic to the meat mixture.  Plus, I love celery, so I chopped up some of that and added it in.
Finally, I used a cup of season bread crumbs instead of the crackers.

Being impatient and hungry, I followed another user's idea and made mini-loves in my muffin pan.  I put the ketchup/brown sugar sauce on bottom, cooked for 30 minutes at 350 degrees, then spooned the rest of the sauce on top and cooked another 15. This was so delicious, I can't wait to make it again - this time in actual loaf form.  Yum yum!

text:
I think the brown sugar and ketchup should be on top of the meatloaf, not in the bottom of the pan. When I sliced the meatloaf, the brown sugar/ketchup mixture remained in the bottom of the pan, so I tried to invert the pan so that the mixture would drain into and flavor the meatloaf.  This was a disaster - the sauce splattered all over the kitchen.  I just don't see the point of having the brown sugar/ketchup in the bottom of the pan as it didn't flavor the meat much.  It should be on top.

text:
Delicious. I did make one alteration though. I don't like to make meatloaf in a loaf pan as i find the meat just sits in the grease. I formed my meat loaf, put it in a large casserole dish and put the glaze on the top. I was able to drain the grease 3 or 4 times during the cooking process. The glaze remained in tact and the meat came out moist and delicious.

However, his arrival home from the war in Iraq prompted me to make this as his homecoming meal: good old-fashioned, USA comfort food. Meatloaf and mashed potatoes. The only problem is, I didn't have a recipe for it. I searched on allrecipes.com, read the ratings and reviews for each recipe, only wanting to make the BEST for my dear hubby. Alas, I picked this recipe out of all the others and made it. My very first attempt at making meatloaf! It was easy to follow and my husband almost fainted when he realized what he was getting for dinner! He LOVED it and even more amazing, I (the world's biggest anti-meatloaf person) loved it as well. This is our new favorite dinner, and I really want to thank you all for rating this, which drew my attention to it-most of all, I want to thank Starbuck for posting this recipe!!!

I don't know how I missed reviewing this!  I HATE meatloaf.  I can't stand it.  I LOVE this recipe!  I did make changes based on everyone else's reviews.  Here's what I did:
1.) I cut the brown sugar in the sauce in half
2.) I added a Tablespoon of Worcestshire sauce to the sauce.
3.) I put the sauce on top of the meatloaf.
4.) I only used 1/2c. milk, not 3/4c.
5.) I used seasoned salt instead of table salt.
6.) I used 1 package of dry onion soup mix instead of an onion.
7.) I used Progresso Italian Seasoned Bread Crumbs instead of cracker crumbs.

With these changes, I made the BEST meatloaf I have ever eaten (and like I said, I don't even like meatloaf!).  This has become a weekly request.  Thank you!  I am so happy I found this recipe!

text:
I've made this a number of times now and I have learned a few lessons: First use a flat jelly roll pan, it gives you more delicious crust and glaze and keeps the loaf from stewing in its own fat.  Second, line the pan with aluminum foil, otherwise you will have a sticky mess that you cannot soak off.  Third, put the brown sugar glaze on top, it flavors the loaf more.  Fourth, use coarse ground chunk, lots of flavor and the coarse makes it easier for you to mix the loaf lightly.

I wasnt exactly impressed with this recipe for the simple fact that I have been topping my meatloaf with equal parts of brn sugar & ketchup for years. The meatloaf its self was pretty boring and I think I was looking for some umph. So I made it a second time added kc masterpiece BBQ seasoning, garlic worcestershire, and some italian bread crumbs, chopped green pepper, red onion, paprika, oregano, basically I kept adding until I had the smell I wanted . Turned out better with more zest to match the topping. My family thought it was spot on. Save yourself the hassle mix the brown sugar and ketchup and just top your meatloaf halfway through. So much easier with the same taste result. So I will continue to make with these changes and that vaults this into a 5 star in my book. My 8 and 5 year old boys ate more than I did exclaiming how I should make it again. BBQ seasoning in the meatloaf is a must! Make in cupcake pans and top with mashed potatoes that have been died with pureed beets for the perfect April fools dinner.

text:
My favorite recipe from Allrecipes! Most meatloafs taste like hamburgers but this one is better. I used 1/4 br. sugar, 1 egg and omitted the milk. I added 1 garlic clove, 1 TBL worchester sauce, packet of onion mix instead of raw onion. The cracker crumbs could also be replaced with seasoned bread crumbs. We sure to put bread end pieces on the bottom to soak up the grease plus it's helpful if the meatloaf is overcooked, the bread prevents the bottom from being burnt.  I don't bother doing layers, it is easier to mix everything with the ground beef and it still tastes great!

text:
The key to making this recipe AMAZING is to listen to the most helpful reviews. If you do what the top 5 most helpful reviews say to do, then this meatloaf can't get much better!! For convenience, here are the recommended changes:

1. Use the brown sugar and ketchup as a GLAZE instead of putting them on the bottom. Use 1/4 cup of brown sugar instead of 1/2 cup, add 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce, mix these 3 ingredients separately, and pour it on top of the formed loaf evenly (I recommend putting some on the sides of the loaf, too).

2. For the meatloaf mixture, use 1/2 cup of milk instead of 3/4 cup, and use 1 egg instead of 2. Also add in 2 cloves of minced garlic.

3. Use a 9x9 casserole dish (or bigger) instead of a loaf pan. Form the meatloaf so that there is at least 1/2 inch of space on all sides. Not only does this allow the glaze to be applied all around the meatloaf, but it also makes draining the excess juices easier.

4. After 30 minutes of cooking (halfway through), drain excess juices, let it finish cooking, then drain again if need be.

5. OPTIONAL: Add strips of bacon on top of the glaze before cooking. When you take the dish out to drain after 30 minutes, flip the bacon strips. Flipping the bacon in the glaze may seem awkward and messy, but it turns out beautifully when the cooking is finished.

My wife, who normally hates meatloaf, LOVED this.

text:
This is the best meatloaf I have ever had or made. The brown sugar is what does it! I ran out of ketcup so I ended up using half BBQ sauce/half ketchup and it was fantastic. I may just do that on purpose next time! For those reviewers who didn't like the idea of the sauce on the bottom, you are mistaken! The sauce on the bottom marinates the meat almost thoroughly because its melds with grease (necessary for juicy meatloaf) and keeps the meat moist and flavorful. Putting the sauce on top only allows the oven heat to dry it out. Trust me. Don't change anything about this recipe! I will never use another meatloaf recipe again. Oh and one last thing, I always serve with mashed potatoes!

text:
Great base recipe but like some others mentioned - needs a little more flavour.   Have been making this similar recipe for decades.  I use a packette of dry onion soup mix in with the meatloaf - cheating but it does add such flavour.
And use more ketchup and put the ginger in with the brown sugar and ketchup.  
Put the meatloaf in the pan and cook it for 30 minutes then invert it onto a tray with sides and apply the ketchup sugar combo as a glaze.  This way the grease can drain off and the glaze gets a nice caramlized texture.

text:
OK, here I go.  I'm going to be "That Person" who reviews a recipe after making a bunch of changes...sorry. Some changes were made because they seemed like good ideas...other changes were due to a lack of certain ingredients.  I have a feeling it would be a four or five star recipe if I had made it (mostly) as written.  I am writing this review because I do want to make it again, and I want to remember what I did and what I didn't so I can make it closer to "tangastar's" recipe next time.

Changes: 
1. I put the ketchup/brown sugar mixture on top of the meatloaf as suggested by other reviewers (this I would probably do anyway, as the thought of it sitting and mixing with the beef grease at the bottom of the pan grosses me out.  Maybe it adds a nice flavor, but my heart thanks me!).  I added 1 TBS. Worcestershire sauce to this mixture per another reviewers reco, but I think it cut the sweet...not such a good thing.  Next time, I may try to add it to the meat mixture, but not as the sugar/ketchup topping, IMO.

2.  I cut the brown sugar to 1/4 cup, but next time I will keep it at 1/2 cup. It should have been sweeter, but maybe it was cut by the flavor of the Worcestershire sauce.

3. I used bread crumbs instead of Saltines - all I had.

4.  I added garlic (very important).  I do love me some garlic!

5. I didn't have an onion, so I used onion soup mix (also based on other reviews).  I think this made it too salty.  Will definitely use the onion next time.

text:
Best meatloaf I ever made.  My picky family loved it!
This will be a staple in our home going forward.

Instead of a loaf, I used a muffin pan for 12 individual loaves.   (Serves 5)
Made the following tweaks...
Used 1 1/2 lbs of ground beef 
1/2 cup of milk 
1 egg.
2 tsp of minced garlic to the meat mixture. 
1 cup of season bread crumbs instead of the crackers
ketchup/brown sugar mix:
3/4 cup of ketchup 
1/4 cup of brown sugar. 
1 tablespoon of Worcestershire
Spoon ketchup/brown sugar sauce on bottom & on top.
cook for 35 minutes at 350 degrees.
I put the muffin tin on top of a foiled cookie sheet to catch any drippings for easy clean up.

I reviewed this recipe before I made it by telling how I’d do it in a Microwave Oven.  I have since done it and will tell you the results.  First, I used ground buffalo but only 1 lb.  I used oatmeal instead of cracker or bread crumbs.  Big mistake, will try bread crumbs next time.  I reduced the water, another mistake, as you need to use more in a microwave.  I used barbeque sauce instead of ketchup and mixed it with the brown sugar and put it on top.  I also used the onion soup mix instead of an onion.  I’ll try the onion next time.  I will also save out some sauce to put on the meatloaf when eating.  I cooked it for 20 minutes in the microwave.  That was too much time.  It was done but the top got kind of hard.  Hope this helps anyone who tries the microwave method.

text:
Great easy meatloaf. I follow the recipe except for saltines were "Ritz type" crackers, and my ginger was fresh for the topping. I also used a splash of Worscestshire sauce ( a bit of both in the meat and in the topping), and pulverized a half of a onion in my food processor. The onion used that way, really increases the flavor and adds to the moistness. I have made this before and still agree the sauce needs to be on top. It saturates the meat, and if you are real lucky even get carmalized edges due to the brown sugar. I serve it with mashed potatoes, green beans or peas, and dinner rolls. I have even divided up the meatloaf mixture and made separate meatloaf muffins, using my muffin tin. Once in a while I will throw a chunk of cheese in the center of each muffin tin mixture. Family loves it. Today I snuck in finely chopped mushrooms, celery, and carrot. It is in the oven as we speak, we will see if the picky kids notice.

text:
If you're looking for a different meatloaf recipe, try this one.  It's original in flavor.  I added sauted bacon pieces to the mix to "kick it up a notch" and incorporate another element of flavor that paired well with the brown sugar.  This also tasted *wonderful* the next day for lunch.

I did make a little more of the sauce then what's called for and put it on top of the loaf the last 10-15 minutes of baking.  To the sauce, I added worchestershire sauce, dijon mustard, and garlic powder.  

p.s. If you don't like your meat sweet, then don't try this one.  Or don't try this and rate it poorly.  It is "brown sugar" meatloaf.  If this is you, try the Rempel meatloaf (also on this website.)

text:
Good basic meatloaf recipe-good as written or you can add chopped green peppers to meat mixture.  I personally don't care for the ginger. I agree with many others that the brown sugar and ketchup needs to go on top of the loaf. And one more trick to pass along-when I make meatloaf I always place a few slices of bread( end crusts work best but any bread will do) on the bottom of the pan and then place my meatloaf on the bread slices -bread soaks up all the extra grease that cooks out of the meat and makes for a less greasy -bottomed meatloaf!!

text:
This is a great meatloaf recipe. It has a really nice flavor. 1. I found that 3/4 cups of milk a lot. I added it a little at a time and found that 1/2 a cup was plenty. 2.I also added about 3 tablespoons of soy sauce to enhance the pepper flavor and give it more kick. 3. Instead of making it in one big loaf I rolled it into 1 cup size balls, pushed my thumb down in the middle and spooned the ketchup/brown sugar sauce into the hole in the middle. (I like to make mini-meatloafs so that I can easily freeze them and they are also in serving size portions.) If you do it this way turn the heat down a bit since they are smaller they will cook faster.

To make it GLUTEN FREE I added 3/4 cup of crushed up tortilla chips in place of the crushed up saltine crackers.

text:
My husband really liked this meatloaf, although I thought it was WAY too sweet!  If I make it again I'll definitely cut down on the brown sugar!  Also, I thought the meatloaf part itself was pretty bland and needed some spices or something to "zip it up" a bit.  In addition to adding extra spices, I think some chopped green peppers might also help to give it a little more flavor.  I also thought that using a whole chopped onion was way too much -- even a small one.  I would use half that much if I ever made it again.  In fact, I think if I ever made this again I would probably use my own meatloaf recipe and then add the glaze to it, making sure to reduce the brown sugar down to 1/4 cup or less.

text:
Before making this I read through a few reviews and made a few changes, which made this a totally awesome meatloaf.  I managed to bribe my 2.5 year old to eat all her cauliflower by telling her she'd get another slice, so it's a winner for me.  My changes: make the sauce less sweet by adding mustard and paprika, use BBQ sauce instead of tomato, and add a drop of honey to help it glaze, and add more flavour to the meat by using italian bread crumbs, using a shallot instead of a white onion, and adding some chili powder.  I also took the suggestion of putting half the sauce/glaze on the top.  Result = YUM

I thought the recipe was great!  I made the changes most people did where I reduced milk to a 1/2 cup and reduced brown sugar to 1/3 cup.  Instead of saltine crackers, I used Italian herb bread crumbs and instead of onion, I used a Lipton onion soup mix packet. I would definitely want to serve it to guests due to its simplicity and how perfect it turned out!

text:
I've been making this recipe for a couple of years now.  It's like the meatloaf my mom made.  I love the combination of ingredients and think they are right-on.  However...I think it's better and easier to place the meat mixture in a baking pan (like a 9 x 13 oblong cake pan), form the meat into the shape of a loaf making the top a little concave.  I mix the brown sugar and ketchup together and put it on top of the meat.  Than I bake it as directed.  After baking, I let it stand a few minutes.  Then, I pick it up by the help of a metal spatula and place it on a serving platter.  It's easier to control the appearance of the loaf and sauce this way.  I don't know...it works better for me this way.  Great recipe!

text:
Sooo happy with this recipe! My mom, who has never wanted to let go of her old recipe for meatloaf, liked this a lot and even had me make it twice in one week! I did make some changes to it, however, so here goes: first, skipped the ginger; next, I sauteed 1 onion, about 2 celery stalks, 1 green pepper, and 2 cloves of garlic in oil before adding to meat. I did add closer to 2 lbs of ground beef, as well. Also, besides the veggie saute, I add lots of Worchestire sauce, some steak sauce (just a little), and I use bread crumbs instead of crushed crackers. Also, I pour a little steak sauce on top of the ketchup at the bottom of the pan. I just like the zing it gives. Anyway, seems like a lot of changes, but I still have to thank this recipes for serving as a base. I was very skeptical at using the sugar and ketchup at first, but now I make my meatloaf with it everytime. It just gives it that awesome glaze at the bottom. Cheers to Starbuck for providing this recipe, it's the best.

text:
Very good--but a little too sweet.  Next time I make this (and there definately will be a next time), I will reduce the amount of brown sugar to 1/3 a cup.  I may also try tomato soup as opposed to the catsup.

I did make a couple of changes on this first try:  1) used a packet of lipton onion soup mix instead of chopped onion; 2) used Italian style breadcrumbs in place of saltines; 3) added worsteshire sauce (1 tbl) to sauce; 4) mixed 1/3 of sauce in meat mixture, and 1/3 on bottom of pan, and 1/3 on top of meat mixture.

Served this with mashed potatoes and corn mixed with red and green peppers.  You need to serve side dishes that are spicy to offset the sweetness of this loaf.

All in all, a great recipe.  Thanks!

text:
I followed this recipe to the tee with two exceptions: (1) I took the advice of reviewers who recommended splitting the ketchup and brown sugar on the top and bottom of the loaf (good suggestion!) and (2) I used fresh grated ginger instead of ground ginger. I'm convinced that the ginger is what makes this meatloaf taste outstanding. I *highly* recommend using fresh ginger!  Regarding the sweetness of the loaf: I was somewhat concerned that the meat was going to be *too* sweet after reading some of the reviews; however, I found the flavors to be well-balanced. Another recommendation: Use lean ground beef.  An 80% lean will have your loaf floating in grease after an hour baking.  Spend the extra quarter and get 90% lean.  I really enjoyed the flavor of this loaf, but my teenage son said that he prefers my traditional Swedish meatloaf recipe.

This recipe was amazing!  BEST meatloaf I have ever made.  I went through the reviews and tried a few suggestions. The best idea was to put bread in the bottom of the pan to absorb the fat/oil.  I did that and it worked perfectly.  I added some garlic, a of cloves or so but my meat was about 3 1/4 lbs.  I also added some Worcestershire to the brown sugar/ketchup mixture as well as the meat.  I did Italian breadcrumbs instead of crackers. I did a package of onion soup mix and a half an onion as well.  We are garlic/onion lovers!  I tend to eye and not measure when I add to my recipes. Putting some of the glaze on the top of the bread in the bottom of the pan, then coating the top and sides of the meatloaf really flavored it. Thanks for the great recipe! Thanks to all the reviewers too! =)

text:
Great recipe, very simple, great basic recipe that can use some personal touches.  I decided to: 1. Made a brown sugar/ketchup glaze and added few splashes of hot sauce. I spread it atop the loaf, 30 mins after it went in the oven. 2. Used a 2:1 ground beef/pork mixture. 3. Half an onion and 1/2 chopped green bell peppers. 4. Instead of baking in a loaf pan, I used the pan to form the loaf, then cooked it in a cookie sheet. It lets the fat run off and crisps the bottom and sides, as well as the top (thanks Alton Brown for the tip)! One last note: only needed 1/2 cup milk, I like my loaf a bit drier than the one in the video.

text:
I do like this recipe, a lot. I've made it according to the recipe and I find that the amount of grease depends on the ground beef you use, obviously. I cook mine on a cookie sheet with sides. I shape it and place it on a few pieces of bread on a cooling rack in the pan. The bread absorbs grease and keeps the meat from falling into the spaces. If the bread is thin I'll put some foil under it, making sure its the size of the loaf so the grease drains off. Everyone loves my meatloaf. I do add a good bit of onion and garlic powder now since I decided it made it even better. All in all, it's a really solid recipe. I just tweaked the method.

text:
Thank you Tangastar!  I love finding a really good recipe and tweaking it to my family's tastes.  I followed another reviewer’s great tip and put sliced raw potato in the bottom of the loaf pan to raise the meatloaf out of the oily juices.  To the meat mixture I added a green bell pepper - 1/4" dice (because me Mum always did) and a clove of garlic put through a garlic press; reduced the milk to 1/2 cup and used 1 egg.  For the glaze I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup, added 1.5 tsp Worcestershire (because I don't LOVE Worcestershire, but miss it when it's not in the recipe - this amount was perfect for me), added several shakes of Cholula hot sauce and put the glaze on top.  YumEE!  I’m looking forward to trying this with Ritz Crackers or breadcrumbs to find out which binder we like best.  Both Hubby & I LOVED this and we haven’t said that about meatloaf in a long time.

text:
This was a good basic meatloaf but I guess because of so many reviews I expected something with a real "wow" factor.  The brown sugar/ketchup mixture is how my mother always made it when I was growing up so this wasn't anything new or special to me.   Just due to experience I knew to 1) soak the breadcrumbs (I chose to use instead of crackers) in milk before adding to the meat mixture 2) saute the onions in olive oil vs. adding raw onion (I added garlic to saute too)  3) sugar/ketchup on top, not bottom with less sugar than the recipe calls for and 4) do not put in loaf pan; meatloaf is best when formed into a mounded loaf shape and placed on foil on top of a sheet cake/jelly roll pan.  This meatloaf was not as good as the one I make with salsa that creates a very moist and tender meatloaf.  It was nice to try a new meatloaf recipe but I think I will keep looking for one that does provide the "wow" for my family.  Thanks for sharing the recipe.

text:
I found this recipe while looking for something that would allow me to recreate an old family favorite from my childhood that my Aunt Jinnie used to make. I followed this ingredient list, but I (a lover of sauces and anything sweet) made the brown sugar and ketchup mix on the bottom of the pan, added the meatloaf (with one green bell pepper chopped up mixed in - like Aunt Jinnie did) and then covered it with the same amount of brown sugar and ketchup. I also measured out the cracker crumbs and added them to the milk (using a little less milk)to soak while I rounded up the rest of the ingredients. It seems as though this step with the crumbs makes the meatloaf a little more moist throughout and it's effortless. The ginger lends an amazing flavor to the meatloaf that is subtle but would be missed if you left it out. The peppers help to add great color, flavor and (for me) a needed texture in the meatloaf. I make this often and my visiting family members who frequently raid my refrigerator for leftovers grabbed what little was left. As soon as the tupperware was opened, they knew EXACTLY what I had made just by the sweet smell of the sauce. This really was a special find for me and my family. It's like Aunt Jinnie is here having dinner with my husband and I and our children (5,3 and 1) while I tell them stories about her over one of their very favorite meals. She would be proud. 

Also - to custom suit our very different family of 5, I make "mini meatloaves with whatever likes a

text:
My family liked this meatloaf. I made a few changes. Because the hamburger meat I had on hand was ground with bacon I molded the meatloaf in a loaf pan then dumped it onto a cookie sheet so that it would not be as greasy. I also split the topping using 1/4 cup of each brown sugar and ketchup on the top and bottom. Because a few people said it was a little bland I  used a mixture of regular ketchup and jalepeno ketchup. Into the meatloaf itself I used fresh grated ginger instead of powdered, added a dash of wostershire sauce, swapped out the onions for onion powder (I was out of onions) and added a spoonful of minced garlic. I decreased the milk slightly, used town house cracker crumbs, and upped the meat to 2 lbs. The result was a yummy meatloaf, neither too dry or too soggy. It is a good recipe and I will make it again.

Oh..my..goodness!  This is absolutely the best meatloaf I've ever tasted!  I made a few changes, however.  I changed the serving to yeild 4 instead of 8.  I used 1 pound of ground turkey, only 1/4 cup milk, 1 tsp of onion powder, 1 tsp garlic powder, (did away with the ginger), and 3/4 cup of Italian bread crumbs. Loved it! My husband doesn't like meatloaf, but he liked this "okay." :) Like others, I made changes to the meat portion: 1/4 cup milk, onion soup mix instead of an onion, bread crumbs instead of saltines, no ginger, 1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce, and 2 cloves of garlic. Because I couldn't spare the oven for more than an hour to cook this, I used a 12-tin muffin pan - greased, with a little sauce on the bottom - instead of a loaf pan. I cooked it at 350 for 30 minutes, then topped it with the rest of the sauce and cooked it for 15 minutes more. Made "meat muffins," as my sister said. Delicious!

For everyone stuck as to why the ketchup and brown sugar are on the bottom, it's for this reason: it was designed to be inverted like an upside down cake. :-) It's a vital step that has been left out. We make this all the time at our house, and we let it cool for two minutes, then invert it onto a serving platter or baking sheet. Wha-la!

text:
Good recipe. Very easy to make. I put the sauce on top. I'm not understanding the sauce on the bottom. Seeing the bread trick on the bottom to soak up some of the grease on these reviews, I tried that. It worked out well. Just make sure you don't serve part of the bread when slicing up the meatloaf. Per reviews, I only used 1/2 C of milk and 1 egg, especially, since I used only 1 lb of ground chuck instead of the 1 1/2 lb. That was perfect for the 1 lb of meat. The next time I make this recipe I may try waiting to put the sauce on till closer to the end of cooking time because some of the grease rose to the top of my sauce so when I spooned that grease off I lost part of my sauce. I will probably make it again. (I have other meatloaf recipes that I like just as well.)

text:
Great tasting meatloaf! I read a ton of reviews and took most all the advice. I kept the milk about the same, upped the bread crumbs to 1 cup, added several cloves of minced garlic, 1/2 c chopped onions and a whole packet of onion soup mix as well. I laid bacon strips across the top of the loaf, baked for about 20 mins, then slathered the sauce on top. I thought the sauce as is was a bit flat, so I added some Worcestershire sauce, 2 tbs yellow mustard, cayenne pepper, chilli powder, and some paprika - I like it to have some kick and a more full bodied barbeque like taste. It turned out fantastic, and I saved some sauce to eat with the meatloaf. Next time I will probably double the sauce, as I only put about 1/2 the sauce on top of the meatloaf to cook and I like lots of sauce :) Will definitely make again!

text:
There is nothing worse than meatloaf cooking in grease.  I place a metal rack in any casserole dish or pan I use for meatloaf.  Spray bottom of pan.  Cover the rack with a sheet of aluminum foil and puncture several places with tip of knife.  Place meatloaf on top of foil....add about 1/2 inch of water in bottom of pan.  All grease will drain from meatloaf thru foil to bottom of pan.  Easy transfer of meatloaf to serving platter n super easy cleanup.

text:
Not sure how to rate this, because if you made it "as is", you would have a disaster on your hands.  It is not edible without draining the fat, and I cannot imagine why you would put the sauce on the bottom.  Made as it is written, you have a hunk of meat sitting in a soup of fat and brown sugar/ketchup sauce....Yuck!

My .02 cents would be to cook JUST THE MEAT MIXTURE for 45 min and drain as much fat as possible.  THEN, add the sauce ON TOP - mixed with 1 tsp. of nutmeg (my secret), and cook for an additional 30 min.  

Also, I place half a slice of bread at each end of the meatloaf after I drain the fat.  This helps to absorb additional fat while cooking for the last 30 min (discard these slices after cooling).

text:
What an excellent recipe. With the 1.5 pounds of ground beef, I reduced the # of eggs to 1 and the milk to 1/4 cup. I added 1 tbsp of Worstechire to the beef and the brown sugar/ketchup and I coated the meat instead of layering the meat on top.
Also, I sit the meat on a rack in a cookie sheet so the heat circulates the whole loaf and it's not sitting in the fat. I would only use a loaf pan if I were using 93% lean beef or turkey chop meat which also, I would increase the milk to 1/2 cup and use 2 eggs. I think the amount of flavor in the brown sugar/ketchup/worstechire marinade would make up for the lack of flavor in leaner meat.
I thank the creator of this recipe for sharing.

text:
I loved this recipe. It's a little different than the meatloaf recipe I usually use, so I liked changing things up a little. I followed the recipe exactly as written and it makes a very sweet tasting meatloaf. I wasn't sure about the ginger at first, but you won't even know it's there once the meatloaf is cooked.

I read in the reviews that some people thought the brown sugar and ketchup mixture should be placed on top of the loaf, and not under it. I will say that yes, the mixture is pretty runny when the meatloaf first comes out of the oven, but if you remove the loaf and put it on a serving platter and let the sauce sit for a while, it thickens and makes a very nice sauce to pour over the top of the meatloaf slices.

text:
INCREDIBLE!! My husband loved this so much, we had it again a few days after finishing leftovers!  It smells divine while cooking, and I really like the texture - much more homogeneous & less crumbly than your average meatloaf.  Wrapped four mini-loafs (not circular) in two pieces bacon around the sides; used full tsp fresh ginger; placed sliced bread under loaves during cooking (so the loaf doesn't fry in the bottom of pan in fat); used 3 slices of bread, chopped fine, instead of saltines; added 2 tsp Worcestershire sauce to topping & poured on loaves as directed.  Simple, fast, beautiful!  Thanks so much, definitely a keeper!!

text:
Great meatloaf. I've make it several times. Even the kids eat it up. The only thing I do differently is that I mix the brown sugar and ketchup together and put it on the top, rather than on the bottom. I've done it both ways and I prefer it on the top. I also add a little extra ginger, being careful not to use too much since a little goes a long way. Another 1/8 t is plenty. Make sure to use ground beef that is low in fat. I use 90% lean. This eliminates the need to drain off the excess fat. I also make extra topping to put on the table. The hubby likes to dip his in extra sauce. Great recipe. Thanks for sharing.

text:
Excellent meatloaf! I've made it several times now, with a few changes. I use a lb of ground chuck and a lb of ground pork. I saute the chopped onion and some chopped celery along with 2 tbs of minced garlic from a jar in a little olive oil as I like the veggies softer in meatloaf, instead of crunchy. Instead of saltine crackers, I use a mix of crushed onion crackers and toasted bread crumbs. I add a dash of ground mustard, a tbs of dried parsley flakes, a pinch of tarragon,  use seasoned salt vs regular and add an envelope of Golden Onion soup mix. I also put the brown sugar mixture on top, but I use 1/4 c Ketchup, 1/4 c Chili Sauce, a squirt of honey and a tbs of Worcestershire. Putting the sauce on the bottom makes it too greasy, in my opinion.  I then bake it at 350 for 1 1/2 hours and let it rest for about 10 min before slicing to allow the juices to permeate the loaf. Guess I changed it a lot, lol! But I think most cooks do to suit their tastes and those of their family.

text:
I would give it 5 stars but following the recipe to a T is only 4 stars.  After reading other reviews, I made the following changes: cut back on the brown sugar/ ketchup mixture (too sweet for a sweet tooth!) and make sure you put it on top of the meatloaf before baking.  Also, I substituted milk......using evaporated milk instead.  Bread crumbs work great (who really wants to take the time to crush saltines anyway?).....and lastly, maybe my onion was on the bigger side of small?  It seemed like a lot of onion, so make sure it is really small or just use 1/1 an onion.  I will definitely make this again!  An excellent meatloaf with a little modification!!

text:
OH - MY - GOD! This was fantastic! The meatloaf part itself is pretty standard but the glaze was phenomenal. My husband and I loved it! I made some alterations - first, based on others' recommendations, I mixed the brown sugar and ketchup and then poured the glaze on top of the meatloaf. I also used a baking dish and formed the "loaf" in the middle of the dish (instead of using a loaf pan). This helped remove excess oil. Third, instead of saltine crackers, I used seasoned breadcrumbs. Finally, I also added some dashes of red pepper flakes to add some heat. I served it with garlic and chive mashed potatoes and a spinach tomato mozzarella salad. I'm so excited because there's plenty for leftovers. Delish!

text:
Easy tip for lowing the fat content of your meatloaf and not having to constantly drain your loaf pan:  Once all of your ingredients are stirred together in your mixing bowl, mash them down into the bowl to create a solid mass of meat.  Then turn the bowl over onto a broiler pan with a little water in the bottom layer of the pan.  The bowl shape creates a nicely shaped round loaf of meat that will not fall apart if you compacted it well.  Spread the brown sugar and catsup on top.  As it cooks, all the grease from the meat will drain into the bottom of the broiler pan and the top will come out delicious.  It is still moist, but not greasy.  And you can slice it like a pie for a nice presentation.

text:
I made the recipe with some slight changes as mentioned by other reviewers, and after making it will make 2 more changes.  Hmmm... after all these changes, it almost becomes a brand new recipe.  Anyway, this is what I did:  1. I added 2 slices of bread to the bottom of the pan (before adding the meatloaf mixture in) to absorb the fat while it baked.  I just tossed the bread afterwards as the other reviewer mentioned.  2. Instead of cracker crumbs, I used 3 slices of bread, which I cut up into tiny pieces.  3. I used 1/4 cup of milk as others mentioned, but did use 2 eggs as the recipe called for.  4. Added 1 tbsp. Worcestershire sauce to the meatloaf mixture.  5. I made the glaze using: 1/2 cup ketchup, 1/4 cup brown sugar, and 1 tbsp. Worcestershire sauce.  I added this to the top of the meatloaf about 30 minutes into baking, so that it would glaze over nicely without overcooking it.    The result: The glaze was awesome, and the meatloaf was good.  I thought the meat was a little tough.  I used extra-lean ground beef and I wonder if there simply wasn't enough fat.  Perhaps next time I'll try something slightly less lean.  Another thought was that I only used 1/4 cup of milk instead of 3/4 cup as the recipe called for.  Perhaps bringing up to 3/4 cup of milk would help.  One of the biggest changes I would make would be to fry the onions in a bit of olive oil prior to adding it to the meatloaf mix.  I added the chopped onions raw (per the recipe), but they didn't cook all the

text:
I hate meatloaf and I love this one. This is the only meatloaf that I will eat and this is the same meatloaf recipe that I grew up with, except 2 changes. 1) We always added chopped green pepper. 2) We put the ketchup and brown sugar on top. You can make more of the brown sugar/ketchup mix and have it on the side for people who like extra (me). And you can adjust the brown sugar to your taste. It really is only there to take the edge off the ketchup and add a little sweetness and maple-like flavor. And the great thing about meatloaf is that it is a great dish to use up leftovers. Sometimes, when we have lots of leftovers in the fridge that need to be used up, we just throw a little bit of everything in. Peas, corn, carrots, mashed potatoes- adds a really creamy texture, gravy, almost anything goes well in meatloaf as long as you like it in the first place. Hope everyone else enjoys this recipe as much as I do!

text:
FOR VEGETARIANS: Since I was successful in adapting this recipe, I wanted to share my hints.  My vegetarian boyfriend could not remember the last time he had had meatloaf.  He LOVED it!  I am not a vegetarian, and I thought turned out pretty close to the original recipe :-)   I substituted 1 1/2 packages veggie crumbles (each 12oz package = 16 ground beef) for the ground beef.  I am familiar with Morning Star Grillers Vegetable Crumbles and they worked well.  I browned the veggie crumbles in vegetable oil until they were crispy and oily, giving them the texture of hamburger.  Otherwise they may have become mushy.  I also greased the sides of the pan well to prevent sticking.

text:
Add 1/2 can of jelled Cranberry sauce to ketchup mix! Leave the brown sugar/ketchup sauce on the BOTTOM OF THE PAN! TIP: Put a piece of aluminum foil over the top and fold over the edge of the pan. This keeps the mixture on the loaf and not all over your kitchen. This way the sauce stays "saucy" and not cooked on the loaf. It also mixes with any juice that cooks off and makes it extra yummy (Don't cut the brown sugar for this reason)! :P Plus, it makes wrapping up any leftovers and clean up a breeze. For the loaf, cut the milk to 1/2 a cup, use about 2/3 package of saltines, 1 tsp. minced garlic and 1 tsp mustard seed. Not like Mom's... BETTER! Something great for my kids to strive for in the future! :D

text:
Suburb meatloaf!

This is an excellent recipe that we will use again and again! I did put the ketchup / sugar mixture on top, and I didn't bother measuring the ketchup as I could see how much I needed to coat the top. I used plenty of brown sugar, as I love the sweetness of the topping, and I used a half cup of milk, which I may cut down on by a hair next time. 

I used a slightly deeper pan, so I found it necessary to up the cooking time and I cooked it for over an hour. I seasoned the meat mixture with dried minced onion as well as garlic powder. Next time, I will add salt to the mixture, as I felt the meat wasn't quite salty enough as is. Also, the fresh chopped onion really added to the texture as well as the flavor....I know some other reviewers used onion soup mix, but I personally would not leave the fresh onion out. It needs to be there.

By the time it came out of the oven, the whole house smelled so terrific that I couldn't wait to dig in! This is a fabulous recipe that I will make again. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Easy! Kids will love it; a basic, pedestrian meatloaf. Here's what I recommend: sautee the onion first (I don't like crunchy things in a soft meatloaf - the onion didn't soften much even after an hour of cooking). I used Town House reduced fat crackers; worked fine. 3/4 cups quick cooking oats will do the trick too in a pinch. This is a sweet meatloaf, so I'd limit amount of garlic, green pepper, etc; might clash too much with the sweet. You could very easily do away with one egg in this  recipe. Next time, I'll mix brown sugar, ketchup & worchestershire to form a paste & then spread on top to prevent oil from pooling on top. Chili sauce in place of the ketchup would work well here too. Be sure to use a 90% lean ground beef or better. I used 80% and it was literally swimming in grease when done. The brown sugar top is the key here -- you can change up the rest to suit your taste and still get the "Yum" from the topping.

text:
This is an excellent recipe and I get requests for it all of the time.  The brown sugar and catsup at the bottom of the pan (in my opinion)is to get the full flavor of the juices. If it's on top my guess is it will be dry. I use a nonstick loaf pan. When I flip out the meatloaf, I make sure that I use an oval platter and I keep the loaf pan on top while doing so. Just like with layer cakes. This eliminates the splatters and if the catsup stays in the bottom of the pan, just scoop it out and put it back on the meatloaf.  It's so good that nobody cares anyway.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe full of amazing flavor! My husband said it was the best meatloaf he has ever had and I enjoyed it as much, too. A couple things that can help: I'm amazed that no one knows the simple little trick to get rid of the grease in meatloaf. It must be a secret trick and I didn't know that it was! So I'm going to share the trick with you. Use a large oven bowl and place a mug on the flat bottom of the bowl upside down. Make sure that the mug is FLAT on the flat bowl or it won't work. Then place the meatloaf around the mug. Glaze it and place it in the oven and bake as usual. When it is done, take the bowl out of the over and let it sit on the counter to cool for 10 minutes or so. As soon as you take it out of the oven it was look very greasy, but you have to let it sit and cool. During this time the mug in the center will begin to suck in the grease. Once the grease is all in the mug you cancut it and eat the meatloaf, but be careful not to break the suction of the mug or the grease will come right back out. Another neat little extra ingredient is cheese. Put about 3/4 or 1/2 of the meat mixture in the bowl around the mug, top with cheese, and then cover the cheese with the remaining meatloaf. Glaze and bake as usual. Yum! Hope this helps those who don't like grease!

text:
Ok I'm not much of a meatloaf person...I think I only made maybe 5 in my life.  So I decided to try again and I made this tonight but with a few alterations and it still worked.  I changed the servinngs to 6, so that the meat would measure up to about a lb (that's all I had on hand).  I also added about 1/2 cup of basmati rice, a few fine chopped mushrooms, crumbled whole wheat crackers, 1 tbsp of wheat germ (extra vitamins always a plus!), 3 cloves garlic minced, 1 egg and a dash of Mrs Dash.  For the sauce I used half ketchup and the other half Cattleman's Sweet Honey BBQ sauce, a splash of worcestershire sauce, a tsp or 2 of dijon mustard and about 1/3cup plus 1 tbsp of the brown sugar.  I did put some on the bottom of the pan and the rest on the top.  I saved some of the glaze so I could reapply later.  I baked for 1 hour uncovered cause well I don't think it specified.  I put the rest of the glaze on the top and sides of the loaf and stuck it in the oven for about 10-15 more minutes while the rest of the sides were finishing up.  Finished product was interesting.  I expecting to see this pool of sauce on the bottom of the pan from the beginning, but it was absorbed into the meat.  Very good meatloaf.  My 3 yr old gobbled it up and guess what we're having for lunch tomorrow.. meatloaf sandwiches YUM!  I will try this recipe again, tweaking it to my tastes and textures along the way, oh and definitely doubling it.  THANKS

This is a good base recipe but after reading reviews I changed it quiet a bit. I omitted the ginger and my boyfriend isn't crazy about sweets so I reduced the sugar. I only used enough sugar to make a thin layer at the bottom of the pan. I also added chopped green and red peppers to the meat in addition to the onion and seasoned it with worchester sauce, garlic powder basil and plenty of salt and pepper. I also noticed it took longer to cook, close to an hour and a half. Another change I thought was good was that in addition to the ketchup on the bottom I also added ketchup tot he top during the last fifteen minutes of baking. With all my changes this turned out really delicious and my boyfriend loved it! He has been asking me to make it agian and I just made it last week!

This is the BEST meatloaf I have EVER tasted.  My family said this was their favorite new dinner!  I followed the recipe to a T with the exception of the ginger, which I omitted.  The amount of seasonings are perfect and the rich sauce that is transformed from the brown sugar and ketchup is DIVINE! I baked it in a silicone baking pan and inverted the loaf after cooking onto a serving platter and the sauce covers the entire top of the loaf.  This is one recipe I will be making OFTEN.  The ONLY think I may do next time is to add a touch of green pepper.

This came out great! I wasn't sure if I should put the brown sugar/ketchup on the bottom, top, side after reading the reviews so I decided to follow the recipe to the letter and I'm glad I did! text:
After reading some of the reviews, I decided to update my own review of a couple of years ago.  I notice that folks are putting the sauce on top of the loaf before or during cooking.  This isn't necessary, and I think it takes away from the recipe a bit.  By cooking the loaf in the sauce (on the bottom), you are basting it in the brown sugar flavouring.  With this method, at the end of cooking, you can see the bare top of the meatloaf and ensure that the juices are running clear.  With the sauce on top, it is harder to check for proper doneness.    As for removing the loaf from the pan, just take a couple of spatulas on each end, lift it out, and place it on a serving dish.  I usually slice it at this point so that each slice has more sauce on it.  With the sauce still in the loaf pan, use a turkey baster to suck out the fat like you would do with gravy.  Then stir the sauce for a minute or two to blend it with the pan drippings.  Pour this over the slices of meatloaf and you're done!  The presentation is much nice this way, because you don't have that goopy "ketchuppy" layer on the top of the loaf.

OK, for those who don't like the catsup and brown sugar on the bottom of the pan, here's what you do instead. Pour half of your sauce mixture into the meat mixture and the remainder over the top once you've made the loaf. This flavors the meatloaf throughout and keeps it moist. BTW, I prefer using an 8 oz. can of tomato sauce instead of catsup and bread crumbs rather than saltines. Don't think it needs quite that much sugar. One-fourth cup is sufficient and a dash of worchester in the sauce is good as well,

text:
This was awesome and moist.  I do think there is a little too much milk, I had to add breadcrumbs so it wasn't so wet.  I did add a package of onion soup mix instead of an onion.  I also added about 3 cloves of garlic.  I mixed together the ketchup and brown sugar and added just enough to the bottom of the dish to cover it.  I put the rest on the top.  Next time I make this I will slightly reduce the amount of sauce, it was a lot.  But overall this was delicious (with the changes I would give it a 5) and I will be making it again.  I dinged it a star just because I thought the package of onion soup mix was a fairly significant change.  It did cook perfectly in a glass loaf pan in 1 hour and the juices at the bottom were great on potatoes. *Update:  I made the leftovers as a meatloaf sandwich for the BF with onions, tomatoes, a good sharp cheddar and garlic aioli on toasted sourdough and he said it was amazing.

This is the best meatloaf ever! I did make quite a few modifications after reading the reviews, plus some of my own, which I will list.
1. I only used 1/4 cup of brown sugar and added worcestershire sauce to the glaze. 2. I only used 1/2 cup of milk and it was plenty 3. I put a small layer of the sauce on the bottom of the pan and put the rest on the top of the meatloaf and it came out perfect.  Smelled and tasted delicious!

text:
Best meatloaf I've ever had and my family agreed! I read through the reviews and looked at the pictures... it seems like almost everyone suggests to put the sugar and ketchup on the top WITHOUT even trying the actual recipe instructions. I was hesitant as well (we all grew up with sweetened ketchup baked on top of the meatloaf), but I went for it anyway. So glad I did! Instead of just the topping that you always wish you had more of, the sugar and ketchup make a marinade for the entire meatloaf but doesn't make it soggy. I would probably use a little less sugar than called for but that is just my taste. I will make my meatloaf with the brown sugar and ketchup on the bottom from now on!  The ginger was a nice zing to the meat also, I've never added that to meatloaf before.

I've been making meatloaf with brown sugar for a long time.I started doing that to get my kids to eat it.I thought I was the only one! Mine is a little different.Sometimes I wrap the meatloaf in bacon. I mix ketchup,a little mustard or Dijon mustard WITH the brown sugar and spread that on top a few minutes before the loaf is done.I make sure to put enough on it that it drizzles down the sides.I have a teen daughter who usually doesn't like  meat and she even eats it.I don't use anything like ginger or onion pieces in mine or my kids would definitely not eat it! I sometimes use a meatloaf mix(anything cheap)I cook for 4 kids/2 adults so on a budget.I don't understand why sometimes people who write these recipes throw stuff in that your average parents at home doesn't have.Ginger is not something we use and def not running out to the store for some just for meatloaf.If I don't have a mix on hand I use salt,pepper,bread crumbs,eggs,milk and I always tear apart a couple of pieces of bread to go in it.If ya want more grab whatever is on hand.I've used seasoned salt and steak seasoning before!I also toss in a little Worcestershire sauce or  steak sauce when mixing it up.I use whatever ground beef is on sale.My family eats it so fast I always have to make 2 or more.If ya want kids to eat something just adding the brown sugar may noty do it.Keep it simple when mixing it.I've added soy mix before and the fam didn't even notice.Doing too much with the ingredients most kids won't eat it

country:

text:
Another review after a ton of modifications were made (mostly due to what I had on hand).  No loaf pan, so used a foil lined large casserole (which kind of prevents putting the sauce on the bottom).  One lb ground beef, to which I added a couple dashes of Worcestershire, garlic salt, onion salt, one egg, 1/4 tsp black pepper, about a 1/4 of the sauce mixture, and 3/4 cup panko breadcrumbs.  Nothing else (onion allergy).  For the sauce I used a scant 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/4 cup honey chipotle BBQ sauce, 1/4 cup ketchup, and a couple of squirts of yellow mustard. I formed half of the meat into a loaf shape in the casserole, and smeared on about 1/3 of the remaining sauce.  Layered the other half of meat on top of that, and smeared another 1/3 of the sauce all over the loaf.  I reserved the remaining sauce to use as a dip.  Baked at 350 for an hour with two baking potatoes (oiled and salted), and everything was done after the hour.  The meatloaf needed salt (I only added garlic and onion salt, and not enough of those), and was a tad mushy (due to the panko, I think), but neither was the fault of the recipe.  Great base recipe to make your own, since the meat IS a bit bland.  But what a great jumping off point!  I'll try again, as per the recipe, sans the onion, and continue to experiment until I find MY perfect meatloaf.  Thanks for the great recipe!

It was awesome!!  Very simple, inexpensive and tasty.  I also used the onion soup mix.  Ketchup and sugar and Worcestershire sauce on top...in a casserole dish.  The only other thing that I have always added to my meatloaf dishes is lima beans around the outer perimeter of the meatloaf about half way through the cooking process. text:
I love this meatloaf recipe!! I made it for my in laws and husband last night and THERE WERE NO LEFTOVERS! lol I did tweak the recipe like some of the other people. I added 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce to the ketchup/brown sugar mix. - I used 1/2 cup of milk and 1 egg. - I added 2 cloves of garlic to the meat mixture. Plus I chopped up 1 stalk of celery and a half a carrot REALLY FINE and added it to the meat mixture. I put half of the ketchup brown sugar mixture on the bottom and then 15 minutes before the meatloaf was ready I put the remaining mixture on top. Also I found that an hour wasn't long enough, I found at an hour the middle was still very very pink. So I popped it back in the oven for another half an hour. Finally, I used a cup of seasoned bread crumbs instead of the crackers. The original recipe plus these couple of tweaks made the best meatloaf i've ever had. I am looking forward to our next meatloaf night!! :-)   Thanks Allrecipes.com and everyone for your great ideas.   Happy cooking :)

text:
I tried this as written, with the exception of using seasoned bread crumbs instead of saltines, I also had a little more than 1.5 pounds of ground beef, so I used it all. I thought it was really good with the brown sugar/ketchup on the bottom, one because I've never been a lover of putting ketchup on the top of my meatloaf, and also I thought that it raised up the meatloaf so it wasn't really sitting in the grease, although I did use lean ground beef so it didn't have much grease. Then you have the option of whether to spoon the mixture on the bottom if you want to use it and I could still taste the sweetness even with the sugar/ketchup on the bottom.

I'll definitely be making it again, a great change from standard meatloaf!

text:
Made this yesterday and it was so yummy.  Per some suggestions I did adjust a few things: 1) 1/2 cup milk and was a great consistency for us, 2) used the leanest type of ground beef available at the market, resulting in less fat drippings, 3) for the glaze I mixed the Ketchup and brown sugar together, and added Worcestershire sauce to taste, 4) spread glaze on top of the loaf before cooking vs. placing on bottom, 5) 3/4 of a small onion chopped well with my chopper, folded into meat mix, 6) used fine plain bread crumbs vs. crackers, 7) used a small glass casserole dish vs. a loaf pan and it cooked perfectly.  So very good and looking forward to making it again soon!  Thank you for this recipes and to everyone sharing their adjustments!

Delicious!!
I followed the advice of some of the other reviewers:

1/2 cup dark brown sugar
1 egg
a pack of dry onion soup mix instead of the onion
No ginger
3/4 cup Italian seasoned bread crumbs instead of cracker crumbs.
I added a few squirts of Worcestershire Sauce to the ketchup/sugar mix

I added some of the ketchup mix on the bottom of the pan, and on the top of the meatloaf. 

It was SOOO good.  My husband was practically licking his plate!
Thanks for the recipe!

I thought this meatloaf was very flavorful, even though I did not include the ginger (didn't have any on hand).  I substituted rolled oats for the crackers because I think it's a better choice for anyone who needs extra fiber.  I took the advice of others and put two slices of bread in the bottom of the pan to obsorb the grease and found that this worked well.  I also mixed the ketchup and brown sugar together and poured over the top half way through the baking time.  It was moist without being greasy.  Even my picky husband, who has always turned his nose up at the mere mention of meatloaf, thought it was great.  With the changes I made I would give it 5 stars.

This a family favorite.  I have made this so frequently I now do it by memory and don't even bother measuring anymore (although I did follow it to a tee the first time).  The only thing I do differently now is drain the grease about 1/2 way through the cooking and spread ketchup or bbq sauce over the top. I used 2 lbs of beef, 3 T  worchester sauce, pkg. of onion soup mix, 1/2 c chopped onions , 1/2c milk, & 3 eggs, 1 C seasoned breadcrumbs.  I packed the 1/2c brown sugar onto the top and drizzled alittle(approx 1/4c) mustard and then covered it with 1/2c  catsup.  I feel with the sugars and sauce on top it bakes into the meatloaf and doesn't sit in the juices.   Baked for 1 hour at 350

text:
I never thought I'd be giving a meatloaf recipe five stars!!! I was a bit apprehensive about this because of the brown sugar and ketchup on the bottom, but don't worry! The brown sugar melts and bubbles up around the loaf as it's cooking to form a delicious sweet glaze. Just be sure to use super lean ground beef. To make it gluten-free, we tried GF cracker crumbs in place of the saltines, but they didn't absorb much of anything - I'm still new to GF cooking. :) So we ended up adding a bunch of GF bread crumbs, which worked better. Despite those complications, the loaf had a very nice texture and was so surprisingly good! Hubby said he'd definitely have this again. If you have any doubts, just try it! You'll be so happy you did! Thanks for such a great recipe!

I think the ginger is what gives this a flavor edge. The ginger flavor is subtle but really enhances the flavor of the meat and balances out the ketchup flavor. I made this with mashed potatoes; I had made mushroom gravy as well, but didn't really need it as the meatloaf is so juicy. This is simple to make, a definite keeper for the weeknight rotation.

text:
Really good. I changed the serving amount to 16. I had no onion on hand but I did have onion powder, I used 2 tsp of that. Also 2 tsp of garlic powder (we love garlic). I used 1 cup ketchup, 1 cup dark brown sugar, 1 cup milk, 2 large eggs, seasoned bread crumbs instead of crackers, and added a few dashes of worcestershire sauce to the meat and sauce. I used the ground ginger but I don't think it was the whole amount called for because I hardly had any left. I cooked it in a pan with slotted grates so I didn't need to worry about grease.
We really enjoyed this, kids included! Will be makes this recipe many times again, thank you for a new spin on our family's meatloaf :)

text:
Loved it!  I made a few changes due to previous reviews and based on my tastes.  I added worcestershire sauce, generous splashes, to both meat and topping.  I used muffin tins with topping on top.  Added 1/4 slice bacon, uncooked, to the top of each muffin before adding sauce and before cooking meat.  I added ground mustard, 2 cloves fresh garlic, both crushed saltines and bread crumbs to meat, probably a little more than recipe calls for but I did have a little more ground meat.  Also, added about a teaspoon of ground mustard to the topping.  Usually I use Martha Stewart Mom's meatloaf recipe but this was a great change that I will definitely make again!  Yes the topping is a little sweet but I like it that way, if you don't then reduce the amt of sugar.

Had a craving for meatloaf but rather than resort to my original recipe (which is actually pretty good) I went looking for a different one. So glad I landed upon this one! I made some of the adjustments others recommended: mixed together the brown sugar and ketchup and added 1 T Worcestershire; replaced the onion with a packet of onion soup mix and the ginger with a tablespoon of minced garlic; replaced the saltine crumbs with panko (just because that's what I had in the house), put the glaze mixture on top instead of on the bottom. In my oven it took exactly 1 hour plus 10 minutes sitting and it was -- and is -- SOOO good!

Excellent.  What makes these recipes so exciting is one's own experimentation.  I agree with the glaze idea as superb.  I read others found the meatloaf mushy and somewhat bland for them.  So I used seasoned stuffing mix instead of crumbs or crackers.  This gives it flavor & absorbs excess moisture.  Also I added a can of drained Mexicorn.  That just makes it pretty.  I put the loaf on a baking trivet inside an aluminum foil-lined casserole dish so the grease would drain and cleanup would be a snap.   Great recipe.

text:
Divine! I took the advice of some reviewers: fresh garlic, 1/4c brown sugar, and sauce on top. I omitted the onion. No crackers, so I made my own breadcrumbs, I toasted them in the oven while it was preheating. Added bacon on top. This is so good, I can't wait to eat more.

Update... I've been making this regularly for years now. I use sprouted grain bread for the breadcrumbs (just put 2 slices in the food processor and then throw them on a pan in the oven that is heating up. They are ready when you smell toast). I use onions, got lazy and don't use the garlic, still use 1/4 cup brown sugar. I cover with foil for the first 30 minutes. This is delicious and my family still loves it. Top with bacon for a treat.

text:
This is a good meat loaf recipe, but with a few tweaks as mentioned on other reviews, it becomes a GREAT meat loaf recipe. I added three cloves of chopped garlic to the meat mixture, as well as a little dash of soy sauce. I added dry mustard and Worcestershire sauce to the ketchup mixture, and I did not put sauce on the bottom of a loaf pan - I formed my loaves and placed them on a foil-covered cookie sheet and then spooned the ketchup-brown sugar sauce over the tops for the last 15 minutes of baking. Also, it took more like 1-1/2 hours to bake, not an hour. For all of these reasons, I gave it four stars.

text:
I made this tonight and after being a longtime user of this site, I finally registered just so I could write a review! It was soooo good, and my bf agreed! I've never made meatloaf before and actually have only eaten it a few times ever... years ago when my mom would make it for us growing up. So I was a little scared at how it would turn out. Well, I was scared for nothing! It was super simple to make. I veered from the recipe slightly, based on recommendations from other users: I added some garlic powder to the mixture (no measurement, just a couple good shakes of the container), I added some worcestershire (I just poured a bit over the top once it was in the pan before I added the brown sugar), and I put brown sugar and ketchup on the bottom AND top (more on top).   The meatloaf came out so moist and SO flavorful, and the onions added a great texture. Will definitely be making again!!

I would give this 5 stars, but I feel that it needs a little bit of tweaking to be perfect.  This is my go-to meatloaf recipe, but I always add chopped green pepper, minced garlic and some Italian seasoning blend.  I also never measure out the salt and pepper, but rather just eyeball what I consider to be the right amount.  Like others, I put the topping/sauce on top of the meatloaf.  I personally like the sweetness, so I would not cut back on the sugar.  I think if your loaf is well seasoned and salted, the sauce does not come across as overly sweet.

text:
My ma-in-law does this without the ginger. I suggest leaving out the sugar (replace the ketchup with home made if you have time - store bought is at least a third sugar), adding worcestershire, quadrupling the amount of pepper, doubling the onion, and you don't need that much milk - none if you use not-so lean beef. As long as the beef you are using comes from a half-way tasty cow, you will find that this is delicious. I give it one star because my mother-in-law likes it, but it baffles me. The bottom line is that if your meatloaf is any good, that much sugar will ruin it. If it isn't, you don't want it anyway.

text:
Very good! Made a sm. (I 1/2'd the recipe) meatloaf for my fiance & I last night. I've tried a few "mediocre" meatloaf recipes lately, and never liked any of them enuf to justify saving the leftovers. B/c of this, I decided to make exactly what we'd eat in one sitting rather than having to toss what was left (assuming this recipe would also not be to our liking). Boy was I wrong!!!! I SOOOO wish I had leftovers (darn!). My fiance thought this was so-so, but he prefers savory meatloaves, not sweet ones. I thought this was perfect, but only b/c of the adjustments I made. I added 1 lg. garlic clove to my meat mix. & 1/2 T W sauce (remember, I 1/2'd the recipe) / 1/4 t dry mustard to my glaze for a little zip. I also ended up mix. all of my glaze ing. 2gether as opposed to placing both in the bottom of my baking dish (which, btw, I shaped my loaf & then placed it in a greased, 9x13-inch baking dish instead of in a loaf pan). I used my WS digital thermometer to gague the doneness of my meat (didn't set the clock; just cooked to an internal temp. of 160 deg. F). Note: you will eliminate most of the greasiness by doing this AND using the leanest meat possible. Served w/ garlic mashed potatoes, cauliflower/broccoli & dinner rolls, this was a very tasty AND filling meal. My only other ch. for nxt. time (and there WILL BE a nxt. time!) will be to add a bit of chopped celery (I love the stuff!) if I have it on hand. Thx. for sharing your AWESOME recipe, tangastar :)

I gave this a 5, even though I made some changes. Instead of saltines, I used one sleeve buttery crackers (Ritz). Also, I put bread on the bottom of the loaf pan to absorb most of the grease. text:
This recipe has been in my recipe box since 2004, just waiting for me to get around to trying it. Well--I did--and now I wish I'd gotten to it sooner! Hands down the best meatloaf I've ever eaten! I made a few changes but mostly as to method. I made mine into a loaf shape by hand and placed it on a roaster pan (the kind with holes so the grease drips through and another pan attached to it catches the grease up) and covered it with the ketchup mix, making sure to get all exposed areas ketchupy. The only other thing I did differently was to microwave my diced onions for about 2 minutes prior to mixing them in because I absolutely *loathe* crunchy onions. I did not use all of the milk either--maybe used a half-cup total before my mixture was really too damp to risk more liquid (but then my onions were juicy from the microwaving). All in all this produced a tender, flavorful, aesthetically appealing meatloaf that held together REALLY well! The husband had 6 slices and I had 1 but that was an accomplishment to be sure :)

text:
I used pork instead of beef as that is what I had on hand but otherwise followed the recipe as written.  It was perfect, the best recipe I have ever used for meatloaf.  I lined my meatloaf pan with parchment paper before adding all the ingredients and then just waited for it to cool a bit before inverting it carefully onto a platter so the sauce was on top, this worked great.  I didn't like the idea of adding the sauce ingredients to the top of the meatloaf as some suggested because with the meatloaf cooking uncovered I felt that maybe the sugar topping would start to burn before the meatloaf was cooked. The texture of the finished meatloaf was really good, it was solid enough that you could slice thinly if desired without being too dense, definitely we'll be using this again, thanks for sharing the recipe.

Yummo ! :-)  I have been making this meatloaf for years.  But 2 things I do differently. 1, is that I carmelize the onions in a fry pan and then add them to the meatloaf mixture...more flavor. :-) And 2, (I learned this from Paula Dean from the Food Network)...put 2 to 3 slices of bread in the bottom of the pan to soak up the grease as it is cooking.  And then just throw away the grease soaked bread after it is done cooking. Happy Eating ! :-)

I follow this recipe almost exactly. I do double the sauce. I mix the ketchup and brown sugar together. (That just makes more sense to me) I put less than half on the bottom of the pan and the rest on top of the meat. I do add a splash or 2 of Worcestershire to the glaze. I also cut back on the milk...I only add like 1/2 a cup of milk. I also omit the salt. I think the saltine crackers provide enough salt. I made this recipe for the second time tonight and my husband said, "Aren't you glad you found this recipe" And my son said, "I wish this stuff (glaze) was all over the sides." The glaze is sweet, so if you don't prefer the sweet taste you could cut back on the brown sugar. This is a keeper for us. Thanks for sharing this great recipe!

text:
Best Meatloaf Recipe I have ever used!

My Modifications: 

-Used ground beef rather than sirloin 
-Add 1/2 medium green bell pepper finely chopped
-Use Oatmeal in place of Bread Crumbs/Crackers
-Use only 1/4 ketchup and brown sugar (divide this - 1/2 on the bottom and 1/2 on the top of the meatloaf)
-Bake 45 mins on 350 degrees, remove from oven, dump excess juices, and bake another 15 mins.

I have made this recipe probably 15 times, and it is amazing!I have gotten so many compliments, and one of my friends doesn't even like meatloaf and has actually requested this a second time after trying it the 1st time I cooked for her!

This is an excellent recipe! I followed the directions with the exception of a few changes. I used top sirloin ground beef added about a tbsp of minced garlic and used italian style bread crumbs instead of saltines. I also mixed the brown sugar (1/2 cup) and kethup together and spooned over the top of the meatloaf prior to baking. Fantastic!! You'll want to place loaf pan on a baking sheet for the juices to overflow onto. I drained the loaf pan about a third of the way through baking to cut down on fat. Everyone loved this recipe!!

text:
This meatloaf is REALLY good. Thanks to the other reviewers, I was able to tweak the recipe to make it really good. I used 1/2 cup milk, 1/4 cup of brown sugar (I could not imagine using 1/2 cup, that'd be too much), 1 tsp salt, 1 envelope of onion soup/dip mix instead of the onion, omitted the ginger, used 1 cup of saltine crackers, and added a tbsp of Worchestire sauce to both the sauce and the meat mix. I did add 2 tbsp of minced onion to the sauce mix though. I also poured the sauce over the meatloaf instead of putting it at the bottom of the pan. Finally I used 1.3 lbs of pre-packaged Italian-seasoned ground turkey (Shady Brook brand works really well). I was a little worried about being able to tell that it wasn't beef, but you could NOT tell the difference, the turkey was AWESOME. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed it, though he said it was a little salty, so next time I might try using unsalted Saltine crackers instead.

I cook meatloaf without a loaf pan; I line a jelly roll pan with tin foil and place a cooling rack on top of that.  Then place the loaf on the rack; the fat just ends up dripping off the loaf. text:
Yummy! I made this recipe for my dad. It is very simple. Like others. I reduced ketchup and brown sugar to 1/4c. I used dark sugar btw. I added 1 tbsp. worcestershire sauce to beef mixture. Probably could have put a little more. Used less milk and agree that only 1 egg is needed. I used whole wheat ritz and whole wheat saltine mix. I made mix of the ketchup and brown sugar in a seperate bowl and added a few splashes of worcestershire sauce then brushed mixture on top of loaf. I did had to make extra sauce after baking for my dad to spread on (he's a sauce kind of guy). AS OTHERS HAVE STATED USE BEEF HIGHER THAN 80/20 unless you love grease. Although after a few hours after serving, the meatloaf absorbed some of the grease and other moisture and turned out even better than it was immediately served. I think is a great second day meal!! This is sooo easy and quick to make. Beef selection is the most important.

This recipes is delicious. The wonderful flavor of the brown sugar and the catsup really made my family enjoy it. However, after making it several times I have decided that it comes out best when you put the brown sugar and the catsup in the middle of the loaf. On the bottom it gets lost in the juices from the meat, on the top it ends up crispy and unenjoyable, but in the middle it seems to be just right. Try it and see what you think.

Wow! This was fantastic, simply the best meatloaf I have ever had! I only made a few changes. I only had 1 lb of beef so I adjusted a few ingredients. I used 1/4 cup of milk initially but then added a little more into the mix later. I used a little less than 1/4 cup of packed brown sugar, putting about 1/2 on the bottom (with a little "zig zag" of ketchup on top of it) and the rest on top (with another little "zig zag" of ketchup). I also substituted about 1 cup of bread crumbs for the saltine crackers. The last change was to sauté the onions in butter before adding them to the beef mix. All the other ingredients I left the same as portioned for 1 1/2 lbs of beef. Great recipe - thank you for sharing it!

text:
This meatloaf is excellent!  Yum!  However, only 4 stars because as written it is only so-so.  After reading the reviews I cut the brown sugar in half and am very glad I did - the meatloaf was plenty sweet and I may use even less next time.  I mixed the brown sugar with the ketchup and added a bit of worcestershire sauce, then spread this over the top of the loaf (heeded the warnings of others about spattering :)).  I used oats instead of the saltines and ended up needing to add ~1/4 c. more.  I only used ~1/4 c. milk and that was plenty - the mix was soupy enough without the extra.  I also used ground turkey, just a personal preference (and it's what I had in the fridge).  But, at the end of the day, this meatloaf is FABULOUS.  It comes out moist and delicious.  My husband has requested that I make it much more often.  Yum :)

i unexpectantly bought 2 lbs. of nice looking meatloaf mix (about 60% beef/40% pork) at my grocers, then went online to allrecipes looking for a good recipe & found this one. the only changes i made were by slightly rounding up the spices & onion to accommodate the additional amount of meat, using club crackers instead of saltines (what i had on hand) & baking the meatloaf for 1 1/2 hours. afterward i carefully poured off the excess fat from the bottom of the pan. that wasn't too difficult since it has risen to the top of the delicious brown sugar-catsup sauce. this had a nice kick from the ginger too. my family devoured every bite! many thanks starbuck!

I would say that similar to the American Lasagna on this site, this recipe is way better the next day and I would suggest making it ahead of time if you can.  Thanks for a great recipe Starbuck and I will definitely make it again.

text:
I made the recipe exactly as directed.  My family loved it.  Even my ten year old, who, when finding out we were having meatloaf said, "Ewww!" loved it.  Just be warned that this is a VERY sweet tasting meatloaf.  My taste buds weren't prepared before I took my first bite.  It made excellent sandwiches the next day.  One suggestion that was not mentioned in the cooking instructions:  After you take the meatloaf out of the oven let it sit for five minutes.  Then cut it into slices.  Use tongs to move the slices from the baking dish to a platter.  After all the slices are removed use a wisk to blend the meat juices with the brown sugar / ketchup mixture and then pour this over the meatloaf on your platter.  Excellent meatloaf.  The only thing I would do differently would be to cut back on the brown sugar next time.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
I made 1 ½ recipes to accommodate the number of guests. Mixed the ketchup and brown sugar together. Blended the remaining ingredients in my Kitchenaid mixer to avoid getting my hands dirty. Used bread crumbs vs crushed saltine cracker crumbs because it was what I had on hand. Added a bit of prepared minced garlic from a jar. Placed it in a greased 12 x 9 inch pan, shaped it into 2 mounds and topped with ketchup and brown sugar mixture (as suggested by other reviewers).  It’s easy to prepare and delicious. Everyone loved it. One guest had 3 helpings! It's different from other meatloafs in that it’s a little sweet. If it’s too sweet for your taste … just adjust the amount of brown sugar you use.

I have made this a couple of times and each time it has been great. I do make some changes....I use double the meat and eggs,used one cup of milk, onion powder instead of onion (daughter is 4, she has a thing against crunchy onions), butter cracker crumbs and bread crumbs(I dont measure, I just throw then in until it looks right), and I mixed Worcestershire Sauce in with my katchup and brown sugar. I used a 9 by 13 pan, so I put a little of the brown sugar mix on the bottem and the made a "loaf" with my meat and then spread the rest of the glaze on top. THEN.....I placed bacon accross the whole thing (6 pieces). Bake for one hour, make up a little more glaze and put over bacon and bake for another 45 min to 1 hour. The bacon should  be perfect and it gives the meatloaf an added flavor! GO PORK FAT! This is not for the light eater! This was a good recipe that I addd to and made my own.Thanks

text:
8/10/2003: This recipe was awesome. Since I was out of onions I used one packet of Lipton French Onion Mix and used 3/4 cup seasoned bread crumbs. Keeping in mind other reviews stated it was really sweet, I cut down the brown sugar to 1/4 cup. It came out great and my fiancé loved it. UPDATE: 6/9/2018 – Updating rating/review to be more accurate of our opinion…3 stars instead of 5 given in 2003. We’ve made this recipe several times over the years, as written and with slight modifications, but haven’t made it in 4-5 yrs. Tonight, my husband forgot to do a few things. Reduce the brown sugar in half otherwise the glaze is just way too sweet! It’s also better to put the glaze on top of the meatloaf. The meat itself is ok, but we feel it's on the bland side as written. For our tastes, it needs more seasoning like garlic and maybe a little Worcestershire. Definitely prefer using an onion soup mix instead of just the onions (ex: Dry Onion Soup Mix by Faye Watkins is great in meatloaf). For those with food sensitivities or allergies: To make it gluten free (GF), we use GF plain bread crumbs (Italian seasoned works well and adds more seasoning if you have it on hand) or GF Table/Saltine crackers. For lactose free, I’ve subbed milk with unsweetened coconut or almond milk cup for cup with no problems. I omit the eggs for egg free now and have no problems with meatloaves falling apart. 3 stars for a good basic meatloaf, probably a 4 star if the glaze wasn’t so insanely sweet.
