text:
This is hands down the BEST meatloaf ever. It is up there with one of the best recipes I have made from this site. I don't care for meatloaf too much but I have made it twice within the last week and plan on making again this weekend. I did make changes as others suggested. I used all of the brown sugar required for the glaze but instead of all ketchup, I used 1/2 sweet baby rays barbecue sauce. I also added 1 tablespoon of worcestershire sauce and 1 teaspoon of dry mustard to the glaze. I also added all of the ingredients of the sauce by sight to the actual meatloaf. I used 1 cup of breadcrumbs instead of crackers,  1/4 cup of milk and 1 egg, more garlic than stated and garlic and onion powder.  I took other reviewers suggestions and did not cook this in a meatloaf pan, I used a large baking dish and did cook it on top of two slices of bread. I also put the glaze on the top and sides of the meatloaf. I really think that makes all the difference in the world. Both times the taste was incredible and it was so moist. I highly recommend this recipe. Yum!!!! Thanks!

text:
Very good..  My family loved that and that is saying something  since we all have different tastes and very rare when we all love the same recipe. 

I made the following changes I read from other reviews.
 I only used 1/4 cup of brown sugar. - I added 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce to the ketchup/brown sugar mix. - I used 1/2 cup of milk and 1 egg. - I added 2 cloves of garlic to the meat mixture. Finally, I used a cup of season bread crumbs instead of the crackers. Also I didnt put the sauce on the bottom of the pan and placing the meatloaf on top of it.. I felt it would just burn away. instead I apply to the top of the meatload on the last 15 minutes of cooking.

text:
One of the best meatloafs I have had in a long time.  I read other reviews and tweaked the recipe.  I only used 1/2 c of milk, added 1/4 tsp of ground ginger, heaping spoonful of minced garlic, and 1 Tbsp of Worcestershire sauce in the.  I also added 1 Tbsp of worchestershire sauce in the glaze as well. I also cut down on the glaze and only used 1/4 c of ketchup and brown sugar (with the worcestershire sauce).  I put the loaf on two slices of bread to soak up the grease.  I also put bacon on the top and put the glaze on top of that.  I will put the glaze on the top of the loaf, then bacon, then more glaze next time.  The glaze really does make the meatloaf.  My husband and I LOVE this!

Use aluminum at the bottom of the loaf pan to speed up clean-up. Place plain bread on the aluminum, then spread meatloaf on top, so that bread absorbs grease. Lastly, smooth the sugar/ketchup glaze on TOP of the meatloaf- don't put it on the bottom where all the grease is going to be!

This is my go-to meatloaf recipe and it always gets rave reviews! I make it as written with the only real exception being the onions. We don’t like them so I substitute 1/2 package of dried onion soup mix instead. My family doesn’t mind these and you still get that onion flavor which I actually like. Some tips I’ve learned are to  ALWAYS put the brown sugar/ketchup mixture on top and I prefer to use butter crackers (Ritz) instead of plain crackers. I’ve had people that despise meatloaf come back for seconds! Thank you for sharing this family favorite!

I really like this recipe. text:
This meatloaf was amazing!!  I needed comfort food on this rainy day and picked this recipe based on the reviews!  The only thing I changed was splitting the brown sugar sauce by layering half  the mixture on the bottom of the pan and pouring the rest on top over the meatloaf.  What was nice is that you had the taste of the brown sugar sauce in the meatloaf  when it was done.  If you wanted a little more flavor you could pour the gravy mixture that forms on the bottom of the pan over the meatloaf and mashed potatoes (which goes so well together) along with a nice glass of red wine!!   Make sure you don't omit the ground fresh ginger....it adds that extra flavor!!  I will definitely be making this dish again!  The family loved it even my two pugs got a taste ha!!  Thank you!!!

My husband and I had bad childhood experiences with meatloaf, but wanted to try.  We followed the instructions, except substituting 20oz of ground turkey for the ground beef (healthier) and using breadcrumbs instead of crackers (easier).  It was delicious.  Our daughters asked us to make it again.

text:
I also am a person who doesn't love meatloaf, but my hubby does so I wanted to make it for him. I used the mods that other reviewers suggested including less milk (1/2 cup), less sugar (1/4 cup), 1 egg, added worcester to both glaze and meatloaf, added garlic, and I always use extra lean beef. It came out pretty good but the onion, garlic, and ginger did not cook and soften enough so next time I will sauté them in a pan first. I used the bread at the bottom of the loaf but with extra lean ground beef there wasn't much fat to drain off so it wasn't needed. Next time I will put half sauce on the bottom and glaze the loaf with the rest. I also made more sauce on the stove to serve on the side and added a tablespoon of maple syrup for extra depth in flavor. My hubby loved it, he ate half the loaf! I also enjoyed it but will like it better next time when I sauté the garlic/onion/ginger.

4 stars because i adjusted some things. First off i put the brown sugar coating on top no bottom. To the brown sugar mixture i added 1tbspn worceshtire sauce and only 1/4 cup brown sugar. Also i only cooked it for 40 minutes, 1 hour will make it dry. The smart thing to do is pat the meat together,make it into a loaf and put it in a bigger pan than the actual loaf. That way, every 15 minutes you pour the grease back on the meat. It will be extra juicy. The brown sugar glaze is so delicious. Enjoy.

text:
Overall a very good meatloaf, however it was missing something.  As the mixture sat in the bowl, I couldn't pick up an aroma of seasoning with my sniffer.  I tossed in a heaping tablespoon of parsley, a teaspoon of sage, and a tablespoon of worcestershire sauce.  These additions made all the difference for a savory loaf.  I would suggest to others that you put the brown sugar and ketchup mixture on top, rather than on the bottom.  I'm not sure why anyone would want to have a pool of fat draining down into those ingredients.  Definitely their meant as a glaze, which I didn't add until about 10 minutes before the meatloaf was done.  Boost the oven temperature to 375 degrees and you will get a beautiful caramelized topping that glistens and adds to the overall experience of sweet and savory.  I give this a solid five stars with these changes.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
reviewed other people's suggestions (thanks for sharing) and was pretty successful the first time, but it was a little too sweet and salty for our taste.  after more tweaks the second time, it was on point!

mix:
added Lipton onion soup mix.  used only 1/2 tsp salt (since using soup mix).  KEEP fresh onion.  use Progresso garlic and herb bread crumbs instead of saltine crumbs.

sauce:
1/4 cup brown sugar instead of 1/2 cup
1/8 cup ketchup, 3/8 cup of spicy UFC (Filipino Banana Sauce), 2 tbsp of Worstechire, and many good squirts of Sriracha (adds a nice, slow kick).

cook:
use 4/5 of sauce IN MIX (you don't need much to top it later on).  bake 50 min.  then DRAIN the grease (i'm surprised this wasn't suggested that much.  tried using slice bread at bottom but you end up with gooey, soggy mess of grease at the bottom you have to remind people NOT to eat.  better just to drain it out).  added rest of sauce on top and let it drip down to cover the side of the loaf (should have shrunk by now).  bake final 20 min to get nice, almost caramelized crust on top.

#NOMNOMNOM

text:
With over 5,000 reviews, this recipe had lots of ideas on how to make it.  One change I did was to put the brown sugar and ketchup layer on the top, rather than the bottom of the pan.  I increased the recipe to using 2 lbs. of ground beef as I wanted to freeze a ½ lb. loaf for my MIL.  I mixed all ingredients, except the crackers and then pulled out one-half pound of meat.  To that portion I added the crushed saltine crackers, formed, added the topping and froze before baking.  To the other 1 ½ lb. meat mixture I added ‘Alabama Firecrackers’ a hot flavored saltine cracker recipe from AR.  I had a bunch of the spicy crackers to use up and my family likes things spicy, they worked GREAT in the meatloaf recipe.  In fact, my DS who is not a meatloaf eater, tried this meatloaf and not only liked it, but asked that I make it again.  My DH liked it hot, but loved it as cold leftovers, so he could make a meatloaf sandwich.  I served this with ‘Irish Champ’ potatoes from AR.  This is a great meatloaf recipe, and one that I will be making again.  Thanks, tangastar for sharing your recipe.

text:
It was very good, however dare I say a hair oniony. Didn't expect it to be, as I love onions, but for whatever reason it was certainly very potent. I added 1 carrot which was nearly a purey from a food processor. Added extra moisture. Cooked @350 for 1.5 hours, came out amazing. Cooked it in Chef John's Mushroom gravy sauce. Quick and easy way to do it, just melt 1/4th cup butter in oven safe pan on stove top. Cook 1 8 oz package mushrooms (Whatever you have, shitaki is best, but I also tried white) until tender, not mushy or slimy. Add 3 tablespoons flour. Stir to cook for a minute. Then add 2 cups of chicken or beef broth (both work great). Stir until thickened. Then add half cup of cream. Stir and shut off heat. Pop meatloaf in the pan, don't put any of the gravy on top yet. Cook for 1 hour, THEN put the gravy on top  throwing several mushrooms on top too. So good! Serve with mashed potatoes.

text:
Hands down, this is the best meat loaf receipe I have found in years. This is now my old standby. 
After making it a few times following the receipe exactly, I took the advice of other reviewers. 
I reduced the milk to 1/2 cup. I also added an additional 1/4 teaspoon of ginger to the ketchup. Like other reviewers, I wanted the sauce on top (but I also wanted it on the bottom!) So I doubled my gingered ketchup. I put the ketchup on the bottom as the receipe states and then at the end I brushed it on as a glaze. The remainder of the gingered ketchup was served tableside in lieu of regular ketchup.  (And fyi, this is so good, I always double this recipe.)

I love this recipe, and I use it quite frequently.  The first time I saw it, I thought it wasn't going to be that good. haha. BUT it's AMAZING!! I tweak mine a little. I add brown sugar, sauteed onions and garlic, and chili powder to the meatloaf mix. Also, I mix up soy sauce, ketchup, and brown sugar in a bowl, and coat the bottom of the pan and the top of the meat loaf. YUMMMY! :)  (**And as a side note, I usually use a muffin pan, because it makes the perfect portion size!!)

***Update:Guys at work loved it***

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe and did very little in modifying the ingredients. I did modify how I put it together. 
I love garlic but enjoyed allowing the ginger to step up and not be outweighed by it. I added a small dash of garlic powder and an egg, probably more out of habit.  Because the texture was so moist I formed two loafs and baked them on a metal grate/rack, sprayed with cooking oil. I applied a little of the ketchup and brown sugar mixture to the top lightly then put a strip of bacon across each loaf. This allowed the bacon to add flavor to the meat but all the grease to drip down and away from the meatloaf. Just before it was completely cooked I added the remaining ketchup/brown sugar glaze and put it under a low broiler to let it really adhere to the loaf and darken it just a bit at the edges. 
Any family member I have made this for has requested the recipe. At times I have added or subtract the garlic and egg and occasionally have added the Worcestershire sauce to the meat mixture. Honestly it has never received any complaints and is probably winning more honors from my kids on the second day when it slices so nicely for meatloaf sandwiches on rye, with a small dab of mustard.
Thanks for the recipe tangastar.

I am an old woman cook. Old family recipes and good southern cook who always tries new recipes. It was just ok. Nothing special but a good basic recipe you might find anywhere. Nice recipe for new cooks.  I forgot - when one adds a sugar glaze, there goes the dripping for gravy - too sweet. I prefer no glaze so I can use the drippings for gravy. Just mix up some cornstarch and water, add to the drippings and you have gravy. I add some au jus mix or Better Than Bullion beef, maybe some mushroom gravy mix. It's an ok recipe though. Nice and firm; just like it should be.

Since I do not have a loaf pan, to make the glaze, I mixed the sugar and ketchup together and added a dash of ginger and a little sprinkle of ground cloves. The meatloaf came out so flavorful and moist. This is about the 5th time I've made this and my most recent time came out PERFECT. However, I think I may add a bit of diced carrot next time for some crunch.

text:
I followed the amended recipe given by H2OSMILES who helpfully compiled what others had suggested.

I thought it was moist and tasty. But too sweet. Even when reduced to 1/4 cup, the sugar overpowered the tomato in the glaze.

Next time, I'll try these modifications:
In the ketchup glaze, 1/8 cup of brown sugar with a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce and a dash of cayenne pepper and black pepper (the glaze really needs something to balance the sweetness). In the meatloaf: 1/2 cup of milk and 1 egg, 2 cloves of garlic to the meat mixture and 2 tablespoons of chopped celery, the onion, 1 cup of seasoned bread crumbs instead of the crackers. I think I'll add more ginger because I couldn't really taste it with 1/4 teaspoon. Next time I will try with the glaze on top from the start.

text:
This is our favorite meatloaf.  This recipe was given to my mother for a wedding shower 50 years ago and it is called Upside Down Meatloaf.  The brown sugar and ketsup is in the bottom of the pan because you turn the meatloaf over and  serve it on a plate.  It is cooked "upside down".  I use a butter knife and slide it around the edge of the pan to loosen any stuck areas before placing a plate over the meatloaf pan and flipping it over.  First I use a baster to remove any grease so it does not splatter.

text:
A great, simple meatloaf with excellent flavor.  This has become our standard meatloaf.

As a number of others have commented, I do not use a loaf pan, instead I put the ketchup and brown sugar on top.  Often I replace the topping with some sort of BBQ sauce.

Addition: I have begun shredding a carrot or two, and chopping some celery, if I have any.  I then sweat the carrots, onion and celery and add it to the meatloaf.  Makes the texture a bit lighter and adds some more flavor.

text:
This is an easy recipe and a great way to use up ground beef (if you are like me and it has been sitting in your freezer for 6 months).  I made some adjustments due to lack of ingredients but still thought it turned out alright.  To cut some of the calories in this recipe, I used splenda brown sugar, low sodium ketchup, soy milk, and planko bread crumbs in lieu of the crackers.  Yeah yeah....to most that changes the whole purpose of meatloaf but I was snowed/iced in so I couldn't get out to get the proper goods.  Oh - and I also mixed the brown sugar/ketchup into the meatloaf and then used what was leftover as a glaze on top (although I did add a bit of maple syrup to it to naughty it up a bit).

Delicious every time. I spread the glaze on top of the meatloaf as suggested by other reviewers - it just makes more sense. Definitely tastes better with fresh ginger, but dried will do in a pinch.  I made a meat cake using this recipe for my boyfriend's birthday, and he loved it! I doubled the meat recipe and spread between 3 foil pie pans (easier clean-up), and spread the glaze on two of the layers. When they were done I stacked them up, trimmed the sides, and covered in instant mashed potatoes (they're creamier and easier to spread than homemade). He didn't even realize it wasn't a dessert cake at first, then when he cut into it, he was even more excited that it was meatloaf! Thanks for this great, great recipe!

text:
The recipe I found for this brown sugar meatloaf suggested that you butter the loaf pan well.  Then when it is finished cooking, let it sit on the counter for a few minutes, drain off any fat and then turn it upside down to serve.  That way the brown sugar/ketchup glaze is then on top.  The easy way to do this is to place a large platter over the loaf pan and flip over carefully -- worked for me!

Wow, thanks for this recipe! My husband, 12yr old and 9yr old all gave it a thumbs up (and these are picky kids!). I did do a few modifications after reading reviews, but I'm betting it would be just as good as is :) I had 1 1/4 lbs ground beef, so I lowered the brown sugar just a tad. I don't do meatloaf in a loaf pan, it's not my thing, so I formed a loaf in a casserole dish, mixed the brown sugar, ketchup and Worcestershire sauce together and used it as a glaze on top. I added onion powder and garlic powder to the meat (I don't like onions in meatloaf). I used 1/2 cup plain bread crumbs instead of saltines (just easier). 1/2 c. milk and 1 egg instead of how it's written.

text:
I've got this baking as I type...This is my first attempt at making meatloaf EVER, due to my dislike from having it when i was younger.  But i figured, why not try something "new" seeing as we had ground beef to use tonight.  Since it was just the two of us, I halved the recipe.  Reading the reviews and following suit, I added the brown sugar/ketchup on top instead of on bottom.  For the meat - 1lb ground beef, 1 egg, no milk, kosher salt, fresh cracked pepper, 8 smashed saltines, Onion Soup Mix, Worcestershire, liquid smoke, about 2tbs of bbq sauce, tabasco chipotle, ancho chili powder, and about 2 1/2tbs of garlic.  Mix well!  I lined a loaf pan with foil and put 2 slices of bread at the bottom to soak up the grease..(thanks to the reviewer who saw that tip on Food Network!) It works like a charm!  Top with Brown Sugar, Ketchup, a few shakes of the chipotle tobasco, and some more bbq sauce.  Smear over the top. Baking at 350 for 50minutes.  **Update with star rating**  Well, it had TONS of flavor, but was a little on the dry side.  I kinda had a feeling that 50 mins would be too long for my 1lb meatloaf.  I'm going to have to adjust the cooking time and possibly add a touch of the milk, but the Fiance says the recipe is a keeper!

I always use Cook's magazine version of meatloaf but it takes several steps.  This meat loaf was a wonderful and easy change.  The ginger is a nice flavor changer.  The glaze on the bottom gave a nice flavor all through the meat and I basted with it the last 20 minutes for a glossy top. Every one suggests adding this or that but then it is an entirely different dish.  This is nice and light tasting just as it is.  I did use ground pork and beef though because that was what I had on hand.  I'll save all the ketchup, worcestershire and steak sauce for the old recipe.

While I am not the biggest meatloaf fan, my husband and daughter love the stuff. This is my go to recipe when making that big hunk of meat! text:
Fantastic as is. This is my go-to meatloaf and everyone - even non-meatloaf types - love it. I've been told this is the only one I'm allowed make. But here is a substitution: Oatmeal for cracker crumbs. Really, you can use any filler or filler mix - crackers, bread crumbs, oatmeal. But that oatmeal is a great way to sneak in some extra fiber. Another technique tip I picked up is that after it's all blended kind of pick up the mass and drop/throw it down. It's fun and it helps ... condense ... for lack of a better word the meatloaf. My family likes it that way, but YMMV (your mileage may vary).

text:
Have I had better meatloaf, yes.  Is this a good simple meatloaf, yes.  I used a meatloaf ground meat mixture from the butcher that consisted of 1/2+ lb beef and 1/2+ lb pork.  Neither my husband nor I enjoy beef only meatloaf.  I still followed the recipe and the ingredient measurements despite the fact I had only a lb+ of meat and not 1 1/2 lbs as the recipe stated. I suppose that's why my meatloaf didn't form into a loaf nicely that I could cook in parchment paper as I'd have liked. I did up my cracker crumbs to 1 c., however. I also shredded my onion (instead of chopping) with 4 carrots and added to meat mixture.  I divided my meat mix into 2 pans to make 2 small meatloafs, as there are only 2 1/2 (17 month old!)of us eating! Like other reviews I opted not to put the brown sugar and ketchup on the bottom of the pan. And instead mixed together and spread on top of meatloaf when it was done, putting it back in the oven to warm.  I did not cook my meatloaf for an hour but instead to 165 internal temp.  With the smaller size of my meatloaf this took maybe 30 minutes.  It was actually finished cooking before I expected!  I'd have liked to spread the sauce on with cooking time still remaining to "cook" the sauce up a bit on top of the loaf.  Oh, well!  It was OK.

text:
Loved it!  From the reviews I made the following changes: Formed into a loaf and cooked in a casserole dish on top of sliced bread to soak up the grease, put glaze on top of loaf, included:  garlic and dry mustard in meat mixture which consisted of 2 parts ground beef to 1 part ground pork. I also added 1 1/2 tsp of worchestershire sauce to the glaze.  Very tasty!
UPDATE: This is now in the monthly family rotation.  In addition to the above changes, I also use 1/2 a package of onion soup mix in place of the onion. I also use 1/2 C milk instead of 3/4 C.
A potato masher works well to mix everything together and save your hands from the mess.
Another good glaze:
ketchup, honey and worchestershire
Enjoy! You can't go wrong with this recipe.  Thanks, tangastar!

text:
I am not a meatloaf fan, but this was WONDERFUL!  Super easy to make and the flavors belnd so nicely together.  I mixed 1.5lbs ground beef with 1 egg, 1/2c milk, 3/4 cup crushed rice krispies (needed to get rid of them) 4 cloves garlic, small minced onion, salt, pepper, and ginger.  I used 1/4 cup brown sugar and 1 Tbl worsteshire sauce in the ketchup mix. Instead of placing the glaze on the bottom, I poured it on top. Cooked it covered for an hour in a loaf pan and it was scrumptous!  Next time, I will pour the glaze on the meatloaf after 45 min of cook time so that I can drain the grease without the slaze trying to drain off as well.

text:
Fast became a staple in our house, and my kids don't eat meatloaf!  It's the most requested meal in the house.  I poured through the reviews and made a few adjustments based on what I read:   To the meatloaf mixture, I added 2 cloves of minced garlic, a tbsp of worcestershire sauce, used 1/2 cup of milk instead of 3/4, and I used bread crumbs instead of cracker.  To the glaze: I added 1 tbsp of worcestershire, and reduced the ketchup and brown sugar to 1/4 cup.  I did not like the glaze at the bottom of the loaf.  My pan has drain holes at the bottom, and it made a mess.  Using a regular loaf pan, the bottom comes out mushy.  To get around a spill over, I took a spatula and made a small "ditch" between the pan and the loaf, and spread the glaze over the top and into the ditch.  That works wonderfully, and the glaze is always perfect.  Definitely a keeper in the recipe box!

This dish was tasty. Glazing was a little sweet for my taste even though I already reduced the ketchup and sugar by half. Next time I will reduce them by a little bit more. I baked it for 1 hr. It was juicy and tasty.

As written this recipe was great!  However, I made some adjustments which turned out DELICIOUS and moist!  First of all, in the preparation of the meatloaf I use bread crumbs instead of crackers, I added about 1/4 cup of cheese (I added Mozzarella and Provolone shredded), I cut the eggs in half and only added one, I also reduced the milk and added only 1/4 cup, then I added half of a tomato (diced really small) and a splash of worcestershire sauce. text:
I am proud to be the 3,000rd person to review this product!  I made the meatloaf with 2 eggs, 1/2 cup milk, 3/4 cheddar crackers, fresh onion, salt and pepper and 90% lean ground meat.   I mixed the brown sugar and ketchup together and put it on top. I put two pieces of bread underneath, like the reviewers suggested, to stop the grease.  It was pretty mushy when I put it in the oven and I was nervous it wasn't going to come out right.  About an hour and 16 minutes later, it was ready and it was good! The sauce on top was a little too sweet but the meat was moist and everything was delicious! My mom was impressed since this was the first meatloaf I have made.  I will definitely be making this again. Although I will say this dish creates quite the mess in the pan...but most good foods do!  Definitely worth trying, although I will not add so much sugar next time. I didn't even add all that much. Ketchup naturally does the trick.

Holy-moley this is good! I ate with Curried Spinach Soup and it was such a treat. I did tweak a bit- added worchester sauce to the top and put the sugar/katsup mix on both the bottom and top of the loaf. text:
wow, it's rare that I like meat loaf... the only other ones I like is my dad's and mother in law's. After making changes to this to fit my tastes, this is now my fav! Even my husband claimed it as his fav and that it beats his mom's recipes, and her's is pretty dang good! What I did:
I used about 2 lbs ground beef, I didn't have any eggs so I just added a bit more milk, used seasoned bread crumbs instead of crackers, added 1 1/2 tsp garlic, didn't have onions so used onion soup mix, and as far as the glaze... I mixed the ketchup and brown sugar together and also added 1 tbsp worcestershire sauce and about 1/4 cup medium salsa; I then spread about 1/3 of the glaze on the bottom, let the loaf bake for about 35 minutes, then spread the rest of the glaze ontop of the loaf, and then let it bake for another 35 minutes... PERFECT!! Goes WONDERFULLY with the roasted red potatoes and asparagus side dish also found on this website.

text:
This was great! I hate re-heated meatloaf (too dry!) and I had a lot left over so I made a great casserole out of this. I broke up the remaining meatloaf with a fork until it looked like browned ground beef. Then I mixed it with some Ragu meat sauce and spread it on the bottom of a casserole dish. I made some mac and cheese (the kind with the cheese sauce- not the powder) and I spread that in a layer over the meat. I sprinkled the whole thing with cheese and baked at 350 until hot. It was really good with that yummy meatloaf meat!

As a college student, this is probably one of the greatest things to ever happen to me.  I say that with a small warning that I vastly changed this recipe, partly accidentally, but the idea was dead-on and it was SO GOOD.

First and foremost, I literally forgot the crackers...whoops.  I also used ground turkey instead of beef. Other than that, I used 1/3 cup buttermilk, 2 TBSP W. Sauce, 1 small raw onion, and 1 tsp of Nutmeg in the meat.  For the sauce, 1/3 cup brown sugar, 1/3 cup ketchup, and a few dashes of W. sauce.  The product was incredibly moist and juicy, the glaze was wonderful but not overpowering, the onions were well cooked, and everything together was awesome.  I will make this over and over again!!

text:
This was very very good. I stuck to the spirit of the recipe, but did add extra "Stuff". I had small portion of ground turkey breast, lean ground pork and lean ground beef to use up so I used that mixture instead of all beef. I cut back a little on the milk and instead of crushed crackers I used crushed pretzels. I sauted the onions a bit first, added minced garlic, a shot of worchestshire sauce, some dry mustard and lots of chopped fresh spinach. I topped this with a mixture of ketchup, brown sugar Splenda and a dash of tabasco. I baked this for an hour in a loaf pan. Just wonderful.. cold or hot!

Well just like everybody else, I made some changes.  I'm certain they enhanced this recipe!  I made sure to pre-soak the milk and saltine crackers.  I chopped the onion very fine, beat the eggs, and mixed everything together rather than making the layers.  Most importantly, I substituted an acidic, vinegar-containing bbq sauce (Prosser's brand) for ketchup.  It tasted spectacular!  Also I would recommend using nonfat milk and very lean beef, otherwise this is one fatty meal!

text:
I'm not a huge meatloaf fan (I find it so bland!), but I decided to give this recipe a try. After reading several other reviews, I added some MAJOR changes. I did cut the amount of brown sugar to 1/4 c. (I cut the ketchup to 1/4 c. as well). I only used 1/2 c. of milk, and I substituted bread crumbs for the crushed crackers. My biggest fear was that this was going to turn out either super bland or super sugary/ketchupy, so I threw in a tbsp. of Cajun seasoning, 1 tsp. of Worcestershire sauce, a handful of fresh cilantro (the way I see it, you can NEVER have too much cilantro!) I also added half a green bell pepper. As other reviewers suggested, I glazed the top with 2 tbsp. brown sugar and 2 tbsp. ketchup about halfway through the cooking process. The end result was ok. The consistency was great, but it was still too bland for my taste. I'm sure I'll be making this again, but in the future I will use more cajun seasoning, and maybe a bit more ketchup to glaze the top as it cooks. Overall, it was ok for a quick, home-cooked dish.

text:
This is the BEST meatloaf I've ever made!  My husband couldn't get enough and couldn't wait to eat more for lunch the next day.  He confirmed it's the best meatloaf he's ever had.  The brown sugar and ketchup combine to make a really tasty glaze and seems to flavor the meat well.  You need to bake this in a LOAF PAN.  Do not try to make it on a cookie sheet or jelly roll pan.  When it comes time to take it out of the loaf pan, place the serving plate, inverted, on top of the loaf pan and then hold the two tightly together as you flip it.  Be prepared to spill some juices in the process but it's not as messy as some have made it sound.  The key is to flip quickly.  I used less brown sugar (about half the amount called for), only 1 egg and only 1/2 cup of milk. I added about 1/4 cup of BBQ sauce to the hamburger meat. My husband said he DEFINITELY wants this to become a regular!

text:
I've been making a variation of this meatloaf for years. Everyone who tries it (even self-proclaimed meatloaf haters) LOVES it! I get constant requests to make this over & over. I use the leanest ground sirloin I can find. Instead of saltine crackers, I use Italian bread crumbs. I add about a tbsp of worcestershire & a tsp of minced garlic. I only use 1/4-1/2c of milk. After I shape into a rounded-top loaf in the pan, I sprinkle a light layer of brown sugar & do a squiggly of ketchup over the top. I bake for 45-50 minutes at 375.

In response to KIMAR's review regarding the brown sugar being in the bottom of the pan - not only does this provide flavor, but it prevents the meatloaf from getting dry. This meatloaf should come out very juicy & tender because of the brown sugar juices in the bottom of the pan.

text:
I love this one. My daughter raved about it, and she NEVER comments about anything. I was truly shocked at her reaction. I did adjust a little. I substituted the saltines for a mixture of oatmeal/cheerios/crackers, in a zip lock bag,rolled into crumbs using a glass spice jar.. less salt, and the oatmeal always seems to help the meat be moist in a meatloaf. I also added about 1-2 T. brn. sugar to the meat mixture. Unlike some other cooks, I did use the full amount of milk. I used the full amount of sugar on the bottom of the pan, but only squirted catsup over the sugar till it was enough to spread over it completely. Most likely about 1/2 C. The sugar caused more juice than the meat would have produced on it's own, so about 3/4 through cooking I scooped some of the juice out of the pan. This was a fantastic meatloaf! I did spoon some of the juice from the pan onto the top, which was nice to have the sugar/catsup mixture on top AND bottom. I made a double batch, using a baking pan rather than a loaf pan, and when I took it out to spoon off juice, I cut it in half to allow the middle to cook well. Just myself and my daughter, who eats like a bird normally, and once for my granddaughter, and in 3 days, the entire double batch is GONE! I'll definitely be making this one again soon. Thanks for posting this one.

I really enjoy this recipe and used to make it often. Instead of packing the sugar, ketchup and meat into a loaf pan, I form the meat into a loaf shape and place it in the bottom of a glass baking dish.  Then I mix the brown sugar and ketchup together and pour the glaze on top of the meatloaf.  Make extra glaze and serve for dipping. Unfortunately, my kids are now at a stage where they won't touch such a thing and hubby is watching his weight.  As soon as this passes, I'll be making this yummy meatloaf again!

text:
Truly delicious.  I only had 80/20 ground chuck, so I made it the day before and refrigerated it overnight.  The cold hardened the extra fat in the 80/20.  By morning it was easy to pick the fat off the top of the sauce (I used a teaspoon, but you could use anything including your fingers)  The fat was orange like cheddar cheese.   Followed the recipe almost exactly with a reduction in brown sugar to 1/3 a cup. Also used 2- 1/4 pounds of beef as that was the size package I had.  I had to cook it a little longer - just waited until the internal temp was 160 degrees. Really the best meatloaf I ever made - tender and juicy,

text:
I was looking for a basic meatloaf recipe when I found this.  Since I'm not a fan of the brown sugar/ketchup combination, I omitted that and the ginger.  I doubled the reciped (it doubles so easily!) and used garlic and herb breadcrumbs instead of saltine cracker crumbs.  Instead of using a loaf pan, I formed the loaves in a baking dish so that the fat could drain off.  It makes for firmer meatloaf that way - great for leftover meatloaf sandwiches the next day.  My 7 year old turned his nose up while I was making it, but was asking for seconds later on!  He even asked for it the next day, too.  The second meatloaf was put in the freezer for another day.

I made this for a family night at church.  I changed the servings to 137 so that the ground beef would come out to be 5 pounds for shopping purposes and 27 servings (I think) for 5 pounds for the preparing.  I made the meatloves in 5 batches, one onion and 1 1/2 sleves of crackers, everything else was to the mesurements.  The onions really do need to be chopped tiny.  I put the loaves on huge baking sheets, mixed the brown sugar and ketchup together, poured on top, Make sure it all gets covered or it will be dry and crunchy in the area.  Baked for 1 1/ hours.  VERY YUMMY!  got lots of great feedback even from those who did not know I was the cook!  Thank-you Wanda!

text:
My husband and I really enjoyed the brown sugar and ketchup glaze on the meatloaf.  I suspect that it really should've been made in a loaf pan.  I didn't have one, so I shaped the meat into a loaf and put it in the casserole dish I usually use for meatloaf.  It was very moist and since it was sitting on top of the ketchup and brown sugar I had placed on the bottom of the dish, the hamburger had a hard time keeping its shape.  I cut some potatoes and put them around the meatloaf which helped hold it together.  The only other mistake I think I made was that I crushed the crackers way too much which resulted in having too many of them in the meatloaf.  The crackers didn't dry it out, but theirs was a predominant flavor in the dish.  Thanks for sharing, Starbuck.  I'll definitely try it, again.

text:
I really changed this recipe per other raters advise.  I used 2 lbs. 15% fat ground beef, not lean, keeps your loaf more moist and put in an 8x8 pan.  I didn't add any liquid due to higher fat in the meat.  I omitted the salt, pepper and onion and replaced it with onion soup mix and some Worcestershire sauce.  I also added half the glaze to bottom and half to top.  The top was really sweet, but the bottom much better.  If you're using a loaf pan and adding glaze to the top I can see how this recipe would be really sweet.  If you want a sweet loaf put the glaze on top if you want milder sweet follow the recipe.  I just love cocktail meatballs and next time I think I will use chili sauce and grape jelly instead of ketchup and brown sugar.

This is a DEFINITE keeper. So delicious and wonderful texture. It is a litte sweet (and I have a sweet tooth). I didn't even use the full amount of brown sugar. I took a touch out. So some of you may want to cut the brown sugar in half. 

I really enjoyed the flavor of this recipe. The use of ginger is unique, but it's not an ingredient you can readily identify. I think that maybe using the saltine crackers adds a special flavor that you can't get with the use of plain bread crumbs. 

My husband LOVED this recipe and I'm pretty sure we'll be making it again. Thank you.

text:
This is a great recipe with a savory twist on classic meatloaf! Like many others, I made some adjustments to the recipe including less milk (1/2 cup), less brown sugar (1/4 cup and I could have honestly gotten by with even less), less eggs (1 egg) and added 3 stalks of chopped celery and 2 cloves of minced garlic. I also made cupcake/muffin sized loaves and baked them in a cupcake pan for 50 minutes. Prior to baking, I generously glazed the tops with ketchup and brown sugar. It made 15 baby loaves for me which was a week and a half’s worth of lunches!!! Great deal if you ask me ;) lastly, I didn’t have any crackers or bread crumbs but had some old textured vegetable protein. It worked without a problem.

Read all the reviews and followed many of the same changes , which makes this recipe 5 star! Mix the ketchup and brown sugar together with a dash of Worcestershire sauce and placed on the top of the meatloaf. Use onion soup mix instead of raw onion. Added Worcestershire sauce and garlic to the meatloaf mixture. Lower the brown sugar to 1/3 cup. Lowered the milk to 1/4 cup. Used italian seasoned bread crumbs instead of cracker crumbs. AND I cooked it 1 1/2 hours.

So I started this recipe after reading a lot of the reviews and honestly, following the recipe the way it’s written I thought it came out AMAZING. The only thing I did differently was sauté the onions in butter before adding them, but that’s because I’m not the biggest fan of onions and wanted to make sure they were completely cooked! A lot of the reviews mentioned that the brown sugar and ketchup on the bottom didn’t come out when you cut a piece out, while this was true I found that if you spooned the juice out at the end and drizzled it over the top that the result was just as good. This was my first time making meatloaf and I will never use another recipe!

My husband loved it. I only had 1# of ground beef (very lean), so I decreased the amount of all ingredients: 1/3 c. brown sugar, 1 egg, 1/3 chopped onion, etc. I mixed the brown sugar & ketchup together and put half on the bottom, half on top...plus a little more that I served on the side. Also, I used bread crumbs instead of crackers, and I added a little Worcestershire and a pinch of garlic salt to the meat mixture. It smells SO good when cooking! I served it w mashed potatoes and green peas. Delicious, and perfect for a “meat &  potatoes” kind of guy. I was able to save just enough meat loaf to make a sandwich for my lunch tomorrow. Yummy!!

None
text:
It was good, but not the best meatloaf. For starters, the mixture was too runny before cooking. It might be wise to add less milk, eggs, or maybe more cracker crumbs? Secondly, I didn't really appreciate the ketchup/brown sugar placed on bottom of the pan. In my opinion, these two ingredients are some of the best parts of a good meatloaf, yet they get washed away by the juices that are produced during cooking and become relatively insignificant in the dish. I'd advise to put the brown sugar/ketchup mixture on top of the loaf itself. Finally, I thought the loaf had just a bit too many onions in it (and I'm an onion fanatic!), so this was somewhat of a turn off for some of the more picky eaters in my family who don't care as much for onions as I do. Overall, the loaf was moist, flavorful, and simple, but I would just change the recipe a tad.

text:
I made enough for 6 servings (1 1/4 lbs. lean ground beef).  I, however, made enough sauce for the recipe as originally written.  I read reviews and elected to amp up the sauce with mustard (prepared and dry), worcestshire sauce, etc.  I also used some of that sauce to stir into the onions I elected to cook on the stovetop prior to incorporating it into the loaf.  I made my own bread crumbs with 5 day old italian bread dried out in the oven.  I cooked the loaf to an internal temp of 165-166 then let the carryover cooking finish it off. I elected to put the sauce on the bottom of the meatloaf pan and then put sauce on the top about 40 minutes in.  No need for extra sauce to drizzle over sliced meatloaf at all.  Moist and so flavorful.

text:
I have made this recipe many times since everyone in my family loves it. And that’s rare to find something that everyone enjoys. I use 1/2 cup milk, I leave out the ginger, I use 1 row of saltine crackers so I don’t have to measure them. And the one thing I haven’t heard mentioned in other reviews is the use of a silicone pan—mine is red and I just love it. The meatloaf doesn’t stick to the pan and the edges do not get over done. I even carefully cut the meatloaf in the pan.  I also use this pan for banana bread. Give it a try if you haven’t already.

I have probably made this recipe 50 times over the last 5 years. It is my go-to recipe for meatloaf, and if I don't have saltine crackers, I usually substitute bread crumbs or oatmeal- it has still turned out great! Have also substituted barbecue sauce for the ketchup- but the key is to keep it on the bottom of the bread pan and use the brown sugar. I have 6 kids, and they all devour this. I usually have to make 2 pans at a time. I have also used ground turkey when I don't have enough ground beef on hand, or have mixed turkey and beef, but personally I prefer beef, although the turkey turns out okay. This is one of our family's favorites!

This recipe is great!  I do either ground turkey or ground beef,  saltines or breadcrumbs, and I do Tony Chacheres instead of salt and pepper when I make it. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
1. Use the brown sugar and ketchup as a GLAZE instead of putting them on the bottom. 
 2. For the meatloaf mixture, use 1/2 cup of milk instead of 3/4 cup, and use 1 egg instead of 2. Also add in 2 cloves of minced garlic.

 3. Use a 9x9 casserole dish (or bigger) instead of a loaf pan. Form the meatloaf so that there is at least 1/2 inch of space on all sides. Not only does this allow the glaze to be applied all around the meatloaf, but it also makes draining the excess juices easier.

 4. After 30 minutes of cooking (halfway through), drain excess juices, let it finish cooking, then drain again if need be.

The meatloaf itself was delicious- very moist. The glaze was a bit too sweet for my taste. I should have listened to those other reviewers who said to reduce the amount of sugar.

text:
I've made this multiple times now and while I'm still tweaking it a little to make it my own, very flavorful and moist meatloaf.

I made some changes but didn't stray too far from the actual recipe. 

I changed the servings to 5 (it's the closest to using 1 pound of meat), so when I reference a measurement keep that in mind. 

The meat mixture used 1 lb of meat, 1/3 cup milk, 1 egg,  almost 1/2 cup seasoned bread crumbs, a packet of onion soup mix, 1/2 teaspoon minced garlic (I used the stuff you buy in the little jars), and the ground ginger as directed. I tried using bread slices on the bottom of the loaf pan to soak up grease as a previous reviewer mentioned, I've never tried that before and it seemed to work with no adverse consequences, so I think I'll do that again going forward. I also use a more fatty ground beef (I think its 75/25 lean), so while I know that means more grease, I think it helps to contribute to flavor and avoids dryness.

The ketchup mixture, I feel like I dont usually have enough with what it tells me to use when adjusting servings. I make the full recipe's worth (as if I was making for 8 people). That's 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/2 cup ketchup. I add a tablespoon of Worcestershire.  Mix together and i put it on the top. 

I pair with oven roasted veggies (today was broccoli, asparagus, and sugar snap peas).

text:
I was a bit skeptical but after reading all the reviews I decided to give it a go and I am so glad I did.  This meatloaf was so yummy-this will probably be my go to recipe from now on.  I did make a couple small modifications based on others' input.   First I put two slices of bread in the bottom of the pan to absorb the grease.  I also substituted Lipton Beefy Onion soup mix for the chopped onion, reduced the brown sugar and milk to 1/4 cup each, and mixed a tablespoon of Worcester sauce in with the ketchup/Brown sugar sauce.  I applied most of the sauce to the top and baked it at 350 for 55 minutes.   I then applied the rest and broiled on high for just a  couple of minutes to get the sauce to thicken and caramelize.  I served it with boxed au gratin potatoes.  It was an awesome meal of good old fashioned comfort food.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
This was a big hit with everyone. I made it once and the second time did the following which was even better. Now it's perfect. 
I added dry mustard, worcestershire  sauce, onion salt to the catsup mixture and placed half in the meatloaf and the other half on top (the last 15 minutes of baking) rather than the bottom . I also placed 2 slices of bread at the bottom to absorb the grease. I substituted bread crumbs instead of ritz crackers, and onion soup mix instead of chopped onions. I also added a handful of bacon bits, 2 cloves of garlic and only 1/4 cup milk to the mixture. Very easy to make ahead of time. I made two and froze one for another night.

text:
5 stars with my modifications.  Took suggestions & did 1/2c milk but kept 2 eggs. The due to our family's need to be gluten-free, instead of bread crumbs I used 1/2 c crushed g-f glutino crackers and 2 rounded T g-f quick oats.  I also made the night before & was out of fresh onion so I subbed 2 rounded T dried minced onion for the fresh.  Put in an 11x7 foil-lined pan (allowing about 1/2-1 inch all the way around (can drain any pooled grease easier that way), covered w/cling wrap & put in fridge until ready to bake the next night.

Like many reviewers, I reduced the brown sugar to 1/4 C and added a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce to both sauce and meat. I did saute the onions before mixing them in and added some additional spices (thyme, paprika, garlic powder) to the mixture, used Panko. I have been making meatloaf for 50 years and I think mine had just gotten out of hand, but the best tip was to cook it only an hour. All my life I had been cooking it for an hour and a half.

text:
Love this recipe! It’s my go-to for meatloaf now. Here are my changes to make it dairy and gluten free: use 1/2 cup dairy-free milk, use 3/4 cup oats instead of crackers, add 1/2 tsp garlic powder, add 1 T. Worcester sauce. Put the topping on top, but change the brown sugar to 1/4 cup and add 1 T. Worcester sauce. Bake about an hour or until done. Drain off whatever grease you can. So delicious!

text:
To save time and create pre-portioned pieces that are easy to drop into a freezer bag for later (or lunch for tomorrow), I divide this recipe up into a 12-cup muffin tin. Bake at 350 for about 40 minutes and you're good! I replaced the saltines with buttery ritz crackers instead, then doubled the ketchup mixture since everyone always wants more glaze. I didn't grow up with meatloaf but this recipe is SO easy that I look forward to making it on the regular since even my picky kids love the simplicity of it.

text:
I've made this many times now. Absolutely love it.  Sometimes I add red or green chopped pepper with the onion (I saute my onion and pepper in butter or margarine.)  Sometimes I substitute quick cooking oatmeal for the bread crumbs.  And, sometimes I add 1 tablespoon flax meal to the mix and reduce the recipe to 1 egg.  I also like to form my loaf in a 9 x 13 baking dish on top of sliced bread.  When I do that I baste the meatloaf with the ketchup/brown sugar topping in the last 10-15 min of baking to prevent the topping from burning.  Also, I omit the salt.  Usually I'm adding a tablespoon of Worcester sauce and there is plenty of salt in that as well.

text:
Because I hate to review a recipe until I've made it EXACTLY  as written, I did ( except put the sauce on top so it could be a topping) ...and it was delicious, our favorite meat loaf so far. . Next time around, I  combined some ingredients from my old standard meat loaf mix, adding some ketchup to the meat mix, some Worcestershire sauce,  a bit less milk, and Panko crumbs. I just added ingredients to get a moist loaf before it cooked.  It all worked great with the brown sugar glaze and the Worcestershire actually balanced the sweet glaze  also wanted this to be a complete dinner in one dish so I added thin sliced carrots and cubed potatoes BEFORE I added the glaze on top ( (about 1/2 through cooking time) and it was perfect. .As noted, the standard recipe is very tasty too. If you want less fat, put bread slices in bottom of cooking pan and cook the potatoes and carrots in foil with a bit of water and dab of butter.

text:
Quick and easy... I doubled ingredients, finely processed onion in mini food processor.  substituted half the milk for tomato puree, added a splash of Worcestershire Sauce, and 1 tsp garlic powder.   I put half the mix in the pan and placed 6 cheese sticks , using 2 groups of 3 to cover the length of the loaf - then the other half of the meat mix.  (hard boiled eggs are even better - but I was pressed for time).  Then I mixed brown sugar and ketchup and spread it on top and baked 1 1/3 hour.   Impressively tasty considering such few ingredients!

text:
Really good!  I think this may have been the best meatloaf I've ever made.  I did make modifications, but this wonderful recipe and the suggestions of others were certainly my guide.  I'm sure it would have been delicious without any changes.  Here is what I did.  Added:  1 mild Italian sausage (removed from casing), 2 cloves of minced garlic, a few shakes of Worcestershire, 1/2 tsp. of dry mustard, and a hefty squirt of ketchup to the meat mixture.  Used 1 egg, 1/2 cup milk, 1/2 cup Italian bread crumbs instead of cracker crumbs, 3/4 tsp. seasoned salt instead of regular, and upped the ginger to 1/2 tsp.  I also used 2 lbs. of 80/20 ground beef.  I think the higher fat content makes a big difference in a meatloaf.  The last meatloaf I made I used 7% ground beef and it was a little dry.  I use a meatloaf pan that drains the fat into a bottom pan, so It's not like being stuck with all that fat since it melts away into the bottom.  However, the end result is a moist, flavorful, and delicious meatloaf .  With the extra meat in the recipe, 1 hour and 20 minutes was perfect in the oven.  Oh, yes, for the topping I reduced the ketchup to 1/3 c., added 1 Tbs. each of BBQ sauce and yellow mustard to the ketchup and reduced the brown sugar to 3 Tbs.  Stirred it all up and spread on top prior to placing in the oven.  Whatever you don't skip the ginger in the meat mixture; it's key to the flavorful outcome. And the flavor blends well with the topping.

text:
I found this recipe to be different when it comes to its preparation. Putting the brown sugar and catsup on the bottom of the pan makes it difficult to take out of the loaf pan. I turned the loaf upside down on the plate when it was done  and that is the answer to serving this meatloaf, if not, the catsup and brown sugar would stay in the loaf pan. Three stars for the way it is prepared four stars for the taste. One must pour out the grease before removing it from the pan or else you would have all the grease going onto your serving dish. Next time I will put the brown sugar and catsup on the top of the meatloaf and see how that works.

country:
None
text:
My wife calls this "fancy meatloaf" and hates it, but I love it! The ginger flavor and sweetness of the glaze really stand out; before you even bite into it the smell tells you it's not a traditional loaf.

I add grated carrots and minced garlic for flavor. Chopped bell pepper is also a good way to add a little color. I mix the brown sugar and ketchup together and put it on top of the loaf after it's in the pan. Pressing it into the bottom of the pan just gives you a nasty, greasy, useless soup. You will still get some of this soup, since the sugar is going to melt and run during cooking, but this will flavor the sides of the meat and you'll be left with a nice little sweet glaze on the top of the loaf.

text:
Fantastic recipe with some very minor changes. My husband doesn't like meatloaf and loves this one. Here are my changes that make all the difference: 1. Form into a loaf in a 9x13 pan and bake instead of a loaf pan so your meat doesn't sit in the grease. I place a couple of slices of bread around mine to absorb any grease. 2. Place the ketchup/brown sugar on the top. Not the bottom. 3. Not a change, but make sure you use Lean ground beef, 7 percent fat or less. I love this recipe for it's ease and it's so delicious!

text:
Since I love things with a sweet 'n' sour tang -- and my meatloaf with a piquant sauce -- this recipe is perfect in my book!  I've made it several times, always to raves from friends.  The only changes I've made are to add a thin layer of brown sugar and catsup to the top of the loaf before baking, and I also add a small amount of water (about 1/4 cup) around the loaf prior to baking as well. When I made it the first time, = the brown sugar/catsup layer on the bottom underneath the meat loaf didn't make enough sauce.  But this is one of my favorite meat loafs ever, and I highly recommend this recipe!

I will definitely be making this again!  It was absolutely delicious, and my 2 year old loved it as well, which makes me very happy!  I made just a few minor adjustments that probably didn't alter the taste too much, but made mine with ground turkey, did as the other reviewers recommended by putting the brown sugar and ketchup on top, omitted the ginger because I don't care for it, and used regular bread toasted and crumbled instead of saltines (didn't have any). text:
I have been making a version of this meatloaf for over 20 years from a very similar recipe from the old red plaid BH&G Cookbook.  The main diff is my recipe calls for using the ketchup & brown sugar mixed together as a glaze added in the last 10 minutes of cooking (many tried this on their own anyway from the other reviews).  I tried the method described in this recipe for a change and find that, for my taste, my old recipe justs tastes better and all the glaze isn't stuck in the bottom of the pan.  I also prefer to use a baking pan and shape my loaf so that I can easily drain the grease off durng cooking so that my meatloaf doesn't just sit in grease for an hour.

Loved it, but made the following changes.  I used 1.5 lbs extra lean ground beef, 1 lb ground pork, and increased the other ingredients proportionally.  I used about 3/4-1 teaspoon of Montreal Steak Seasoning in place of the black pepper, and I added about 2 tsp. to 1 Tbsp. of Worcestershire sauce to the mixture. text:
i read the reviews and my family really enjoyed this meatloaf.  I did following some adjustments and I would like to make a recommendation.  I did the recommendation of 1/4 milk, 1/3 brown sugar, bread crumbs instead of crackers, 1 1/2 tbsp of worcheshire sauce and onion soup mix - all good.  I also prepared the meat loaf in a jelly roll pan with three sheets of aluminum foil for easy clean up.  Thank you all for those recommendations.  Yet, I would recommend if you use the onion soup mix - DO NOT USE ANY SALT.  I also added six slices of bacon on the top for flavoring and ended up cooking the meatloaf for about 1 1/2 hours at 350.   The bacon was not crispy so maybe use the broiler for a bit to crisp it up then the sauce at the end.

text:
I added slightly more hamburger (about 1/4 pound more), reduced the brown sugar to 1/4 cup, and increased the chili powder to 1-2 tbsp, depending on the heat you like.  I don't like to add additional salt, so I left it out.  Because I had them on hand, I used bread crumbs instead of the croutons, and put in a whole large yellow onion and half a green pepper.  I mixed this entire set of ingredients together, as opposed to dividing them into sauce and loaf, and baked them in a draining meatloaf pan.  For a topping, I mixed ketchup and Heinz 57 sauce and covered it.  I have always loved this recipe and have just tweaked it here or there to make it the most delicious for my family.  I think this version is the final one, everyone adores it!

text:
I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for a very very tasty meat loaf base and sauce. I say meat loaf base, only because I had to adjust certain ingredients to my daughter's low iodine diet (she has cancer and has to be on it for 14 days). Anyhow, for anyone on this low iodine diet, this is the changes I made to this recipe: I used coconut milk instead of milk, egg whites instead of eggs, non-iodized salt, replaced the ginger with dry mustard, replaced the crackers with Quaker Oatmeal, grounded up fine in the Nutri Bullet, and used Heinz no salt ketchup and mixed it with the brown sugar to put on top. It was fabulous- two meatloafs, gone that night- none left over for sandwiches in the morning- boo hoo!

I do plan to make the original recipe after her low iodine diet is done, as I bet it tastes great, too! We can't thank you enough for a wonderful recipe- even if I had to adjust it so she could eat it, it still was delicious! I can't wait to try the original, though!

text:
My husband loves this meatloaf, which is saying a lot from a previously non-meatloaf-loving man.  I make the recipe completely as is with the exceptions of- I saute the onions prior to adding them into the mix and add part of the salt to them as they cook.  Without doing this the meatloaf had bit too much crunchy onion for my taste.  Also I cut down the ginger to a pinch, since, for me, the ginger was overpowering otherwise.  This is an awesome recipe that has become a staple in our household!

I've never had a meatloaf cook in an hour.  This one took 1 hour and 20 minutes.  I used dry oatmeal instead of crackers.  I used the dry onion soup mix instead of real onion.  I do not recommend using the onion soup mix.  I felt this meatloaf was missing some spices.  If you pour the milk in slowly/stir/pour/stir then the milk isn't "too much" as others had stated.  It's still missing a few spices, but other than that, it was thick and tough like a great meatloaf should be!!  Next time, maybe I'll put some of the ketchup and brown sugar IN the meatloaf!! I bet that would be good. 2nd time: I put the brown sugar and ketchup on top and it made the brown sugar crunchy.. not sure what to do with this topping.  I like the loaf though.

text:
The only meatloaf my family will eat!  It has changed their response to having meatloaf for dinner from groans to cheers. The omission of mustard from the glaze makes all the difference.  As many reviews suggest, I do not place the glaze under the loaf, but make extra and smother the top.  The only other change aside from various fillers and seasonings (to what I have on hand) is to cook the loaf on top of two pieces of white bread.  This really cuts out the meat simmering in its own grease.  I wouldn't dream of cooking it without foiling the pan first.  Otherwise the sugar-ketchup sauce would be impossible to clean.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
Great meatloaf recipe.  The first time I made it, I followed the recipe exactly.  Some changes I now make are: use 1/3 cup chopped onions.  A whole onion is way too much!  Also, do not bake this in a regular loaf pan!  I learned this the hard way.  The fat has nowhere to drain off to, so the loaf will end up baking in its own fat and it will turn out too greasy.  Use a special meatloaf pan, or form it into a loaf shape on a broiling pan.  Using the leanest meat you have available will also help.

I made this Gluten Free with a few small tweaks and it has become a regular on our table. First we use ground turkey meat 93/7 (this is only because I prefer turkey over beef), and made it per the recipe except we substituted potato flakes for the crushed saltine crackers, and in lieu of the onion I used a package of onion soup mix. My kids also love making mini meatloaves with this recipe, just divide into 6 equal mini meatloaves, pop them on a cookie sheet and cook at the same temp for 45 min.

We LOVED IT! I actually just finished mine and it's my favorite meatloaf recipe from this site so far. I followed the recipe exactly as written with one minor change. About 45 minutes into baking, I drained as much grease as I could out of it and topped the meatloaf with a mixture of A1 sauce, ketchup, and brown sugar for a glaze on top. Even my super picky 5 year old (who, before I even started cooking it, told me he hates meatloaf) asked for seconds. This is definitely a keeper! I've put a layer of bread on the bottom of the pan to minimize the grease in other recipes, so I may try that next time. The grease is really my only complaint, but that's with any meatloaf, really.

First time in years I did meatloaf... and this recipe was wonderful.  I did check some of the reviews and made my own changes... 1/4 C br sugar instead of 1/2, spaghetti sauce instead of ketchup, 1/2 C of milk instead of 3/4 and I added worchester sauce and Dijon mustard.  I also used a pkg of dried onion soup mix instead of onion. I had a few problems with it, mainly it taking an hour and a half to bake. But i made a few modifications: Added two pieces of bread at the bottom of the loaf pan to absorb some of the grease, I added one clove garlic to the meat mixture, and i used only 1/2 cup of brown sugar and mixed it with the ketchup to put on top of the meatloaf before baking it. After it was finally done it had good flavor and texture. next time I will budget for longer baking time and add a full 3/4 cup of brown sugar. Nick loved it more than I did, but after all, it is meatloaf.

text:
I love this recipe, I have made it so many times and it is always excellent. I use bread crumbs instead of crackers and soak them in the milk first and then add them to the mixed meat. This makes your meat loaf moist. I do not put the sauce on the bottom, instead I put about 3 tablespoons of it in the meat and mix it around. The rest I spoon  on the top of my meat loafs for the last 15 minutes of cooking.  like other reviewers I used a large muffin tin to make individual loafs. 350 for 30 mins and then put the sauce on top and cooked for another 10 to 15 min. Delicious every time.

I loved this meatloaf!!!! It was my very first attempt at making a meatloaf.  It was easy to make, I took the advise I read on here, and put 2 pieces of bread at the bottom of the pan and I had zero grease when I was all done. My mom has never liked meatloaf, and is the biggest meatloaf critic I know.  She ate it, loved it, and told me to keep the recipe, I am now the "official" meatloaf maker for family get togethers.

text:
I loved this recipe! The meatloaf came out SO moist and evenly cooked and was such great comfort food! I added my own little touches though: I wanted to get some veggies in my meatloaf so I finely chopped up an onion, 1 whole carrot and 2 stalks celery. I cooked them in some vegetable oil just until they were nice and sweated down. I cooled the veggies down and added it to the meat mixture with some Italian seasoning and garlic. I also used bread crumbs instead of crackers. With the glaze, I also wanted it to be on top of the meatloaf instead of the bottom. So I just mixed up the brown sugar and ketchup with a little Worsteshire sauce and added it on top of the meatloaf the last 15 minutes of cooking. This recipe is such a great base for adding your own twist to meatloaf!

text:
Nice recipe!  I made a few changes as per some previous reviewers:
- used 1/4 cup of brown sugar
- added 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce to the ketchup/brown sugar mix
- used 1/2 cup of milk and 1 egg
- added 2 cloves of garlic to the meat mixture
- added some chopped celery
- used a cup of season bread crumbs instead of crackers
I didn't use a loaf pan, but rather formed it into a pyrex dish and coated with the ketchup/bbq/worcester mix.
Yummy and will make again! (even my kids liked it!)

text:
This was a great loaf, but the topping is much too sweet as is.  I had 2 lbs of meat, so I increased everything else in the loaf proportionally (I used 3 eggs).  I didn't have crumbs, so I used oatmeal, and I used fried onions because I had them already.  I baked them as 8 individual loaves (45 min) and 1 larger loaf (1 hr), and they were so soft and moist, just marvelous!  I don't keep ketchup in the house, though, so I used a small can of tomato paste and added onion powder and 1/4 c. sugar.  It was so sweet, I had to cut it with another can.  I know this has sugar in the title, but when I made it the first time (I think with no changes to the sugar), I couldn't stomach the sweetness of the topping.

text:
This is the best meatloaf I've ever tasted, but I did do a few things differently. I agree with the other reviewers that the ketchup and brown sugar is better on the top. Also, to make things easier, I used a packet of dried onion soup mix instead of having to chop an onion. The soup mix also has plenty of salt and seasoning already in it, so I didn't need to use salt and pepper. Instead of cracker crumbs, I usually use plain bread crumbs or crushed croutons. One thing I have noticed - I do not taste the ginger at ALL in this recipe. I don't know if it is because I use the onion soup mix and maybe the flavor gets lost in it, or if the recipe should call for more ginger. I've tried making it with and without the ginger and I taste no difference.

text:
I tried the original recipe and although it was very good, we felt like it was missing something. I altered the recipe using the following changes and my whole family absolutely loved it!!! 
First I formed the meat mix into meatballs instead of a loaf  and used onion soup mix in place of the raw onions used in the original recipe. I also added 1 tsp of worchestershire sauce and omitted the ginger. I covered the loaf with 1/2c of b sugar and 1/2 c chili sauce mixed together(some family members do not like ketchup) instead of placing it at the bottom. It was absolutely DELICIOUS!!! The original recipe would get only 3 stars for us here, but the revisedc version definately gets all 5 stars!

I found this recipe looking for something different to do with hamburger I needed to use. My husband decided he was starving so I didn't have an hour to cook it as meatloaf but I really wanted to try it, so I went the sloppy Joe route. :) I made the meat mixture per the recipe except I left the milk out (not sure if that mattered) and used onion powder instead of chopped onions. I mixed the sauce in a bowl, cooked the meat mixture in a skillet and added the sauce at the last minute. Served it on a hamburger bun, it was good! I will definitely try it in the correct meatloaf mode! My husband put cheese on his hamburger bun, yum!  I will say if you try it this way use the lowest fat content hamburger you can. I already had 93/7 ground beef, but there was no grease to drain in the pan at the end. Yikes! It didn't look or taste greasy at all though. End result it was fast, easy, and good!

text:
I'm not normally a big meatloaf fan, but this was great!  I used BBQ sauce because I didn't have ketchup and heavy cream b/c I was out of milk (and only 1/4 cup).  I accidentally forgot the onion and added about a tbsp of worchestshire to the meat mixture.  I put it in muffin tins and cooked for 45 min.  I added the brown sugar/BBQ sauce mixture to both the bottom and top of each meatloaf "muffin", though I would recommend waiting until the last 15 min or so for the sauce on top otherwise it goes everywhere.  I would also recommend putting a cookies sheet below the muffin tin in the oven if you go this route to catch any grease.  I will definitely make this again!

text:
Finally!  I have a meatloaf recipe I can eat!  Mom used to make a similar recipe that was decent.  But I don't like meatloaf.  Hubby loves it!  So to give him a treat since I have been gone on vacation without him for three weeks (he had to work), I made this recipe for the first night I was back.  I did add the brown sugar/ketchup to the top as suggested by another reviewer.  I do not like the soft, mushy type meatloaf, so I usually cook it flatter so it will brown and have less chance to get mushy--more liquids bake out of it.  I greased an 8" iron skillet, put the meatloaf in, spread it flat in the middle heaping up the sides a little more than the middle, mixed about 1/4 cup of the meatloaf mixture in with the brown sugar mixture, and poured it over the top.  (I had to use CheezIt White Cheddar crackers since I had no other crackers in the house.)  The recipe was very, very good.  The top browned nicely, and it was more crispy (like I like it).  The CheezIt crackers did it no favors (made it mushy), and I will plan to use hard crackers next time.  It was excellent, and I actually had a second, small serving (which I never have done with meatloaf in my life!)  I will definitely use this recipe again and again.  Thanks!  

Next time, I think I will try some flavored crackers--garlic, basil or ?

text:
For years I've been searching for that perfect meatloaf recipe.  I think I may have found it!  This recipe has potential,  I followed the recipe to the T and now I shall make it my own....ha, ha, ha.   I believe it needs tweaking here and there but it is near perfect.   The consistency was excellent, the slices did not fall apart.  It just needs more in the spice department.  I did not use lean ground beef so it was quite a process for me,  every few minutes I had pull the meatloaf from the oven to drain grease out of the loaf pan.  Lean ground beef maybe healthy but lacking in flavor and taste.  If you're worried about what's healthy, meatloaf is not your best choice even if the meat is 92/7 or 85/15.  In the end I like to think the tenderness was due to using 85/15 and not the lean as the recipe requests.  Enjoy!

Easy easy recipe! I used 2 packages of ground beef. I used salt, pepper, basil, and onion soup mix to season the beef. I did as other users suggested: 1/2 cup of milk and 1 egg. I also used about 1 cup of plain bread crumbs. That was the perfect blend. Made the perfect size loaf. As for the glaze: 1 cup of ketchup, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, and and 1 teaspoon of steak sauce. The steak sauce cut the sweetness, making this the perfect glaze.

I changed the recipe a little, but this got two thumbs WAY up from everyone in my family.  Here are the changes I made.  I used only 1/4 c of brown sugar, 1/2 cup of milk, and 1 egg.  I used "Beefy Onion" soup mix instead of an onion, and I added 1 Tbs of Worcestershire sauce to the glaze.  I added 1/2 of the glaze to the bottom of the pan and then added the other 1/2 the last 15 minutes of baking.  I also used 1/2 ground turkey and 1/2 veggie crumbles to reduce the total fat.  It was great and I WILL be making it again!  (Especially since my picky kiddos ate it!)

text:
The best meatloaf I had so far!!! So delicious and juicy! I made this meatloaf on our anniversary, and my boyfriend loved it very much. Highly recommended to others who wants to make meatloaf.   I modified the recipe though. Below is based on 4 servings. I used 1.33 lb 96% lean ground beef and baked it in a 9x5 loaf pan. The beef was so lean that the meatloaf had so little fat which is great to me. I read other reviews and agreed to put the sauce on top instead of at the bottom (the sauce also kept the beef moist). I put one tablespoon of worcestershire mixed in with the brown sugar and ketchup. When the meatloaf was half way cooked, I mixed and added extra ketchup and a flash of worcestershire sauce on top of the meatloaf. It turned out very delicious because of the extra sauce and moist. One advice is don't drain the sauce (they are not fat). Keep them and put of top of the meatloaf!!! No need to bake the meatloaf for an hour, it may get overcooked. I used croutons instead of crumbs. I put in two 1/4 cup finely crushed crouton cuz of more  beef. I love garlic, so I chopped up two gloves and mixed them in.   The meatloaf goes well with fresh cut corn and garlic mashed potatoes!!  Yummy, I will definitely use this recipe again.   My boyfriend and I finished everything, and now I want more.

I'd never made - or eaten - meatloaf until tonight, and this was easy to make and delicious! I followed the suggestions of other reviewers: I used 1/4 brown sugar mixed with 1 tbsp of worchestshire saurce and required ketchup to glaze the top of the meatloaf after 20-30minutes for a total 1.5 hours cooking time. I used 1/2 cup milk (rather than the 3/4 cup in the ingredients list),  also added 3 cloves of garlic and 1 tbsp worchestshire sauce to the meat mixture.  I'll definitely make this again!

text:
I've made this probably 5-6 times - absolutely LOVE IT! Of course, I do change it just a bit - I decrease the amount of brown sugar - about 1/4 cup. I mix the brown sugar and ketchup together and add a couple dashes of worcestershire then spread it on top of the meatloaf. Also I saute the onion with some garlic (and celery if I have any) and add that to the meat before forming it into a loaf and putting it on a baking sheet - this way it doesn't sit in as much grease. Oh and I use 2 egg whites and 93/7 beef. BF loves it as must as I do!

Great recipe and easy to make.  My husband and I love it.  Made a few minor changes though... Sometimes I double the ketchup mixture (reserving half of it) because we like to add extra on our plates.

This was awsome!  I tweeked it a little: 1st, I added about 1/4 lb ground sausage for flavor.  Next, I used bread crumbs instead of crakers.  Then, for the glaze, I added 1/4 cup mustard and 2 TBS Worchester sause, and I spread this on top, instead of the botom.  And finally, I placed 2 slices of bread at the bottom of the pan to absorb most of the fat.  Fabulous!!!  Also, if you're short on time, I shape these into hamburger patties, spread the sause on each one and bake at 425 for about 30 minutes.  They make the BEST burgers!  We love this recipe!  Thank you!

text:
This is a very good meatloaf recipe!  However, the first time I made it, the chopped onion was too overwhelming/too obvious.  Maybe I didn't chop it small enough, because we were getting slightly raw chunks of onions as we bit into the meat.  I just made this for a second time with some revisions, which suited my family much better.  I like my meatloaf to have a little bit of a tomato flavor, and so I added 1/4 cup of ketchup and reduced the amount of milk to 1/2 cup so the meat wouldn't fall apart.  I also substituted 1 tsp of dried minced onions for the chopped fresh onion and 3/4 cup of bread crumbs for the cracker crumbs.  Next time, I think I will also be grating some zucchini and carrots into it in the hopes that I can get my toddler to eat some veggies.  With my revisions, the recipe became a 5 star recipe for my family, and I will definitely be making meatloaf this way from now on!

Very good recipe.  I make this meatloaf all the time.  The only change I make is that I use oats instead of saltines.  I also cook it on a rack in a pan like other reviewers have suggested and spread the ketchup mixture over top (I only use 1/4 brown sugar and 1/4 ketchup). text:
I dont like meatloaf, but I make this all the time and I love it! I use 3/4c of italian breadcrumbs because thier already mostly seasoned. But I also add 1ts garlic powder, 2ts of onion powder (we dont like onions in our house), 1ts salt, 1/2ts pepper, 1/2ts ginger, and 1tbs of brown sugar. I use only 1/4c of ketchup and 1/4c of worchestire. I use 2 pieces of bread on the bottom of the pan.I use 1/4 of the sauce on the top not the bottom and cook for 45 mins and then flip it over onto a plate, remove the bread and flip it back into the pand and add 1/4 more of the sauce. Let it cook for 15 more mins and take it out  add 1/4 more let it rest 15 mins, slice it and add the rest of the sauce. This is a keeper!!!

A family favorite! Even my husband, who normally does not care for meatloaf, requests this. The recipe is perfect as written, however I do make a few minor changes just to speed up the preparation a bit...I use a packet of dry onion soup mix in place of the chopped onion and salt. I use seasoned bread crumbs in place of the crushed crackers. I also mix the ketchup and brown sugar together and pour the sauce over the top before baking. We eat this on top of mashed potatoes. YUMMY!!

text:
My first meatloaf and it was good!  I followed the recipe for about 12 and then followed many sugestions.  I used a pyrex 9 X 13 and had the meatloaf sit on top of 4 pieces of bread.  On the bread I sprinkled a little brown sugar and ketcup.  In the meatloaf- I used 1/2 c of milk and 2 eggs.  I bought Lipton onion soup but they had one for beef so I used that one and I chopped up a small onion.  I also mixed in about 1 cup of Italian breadcrumbs instead of cracker crumbs.  I added about 2 Tsp of minced garlic and about 2 T of ketchup within the beef.  I used all other ingredients as indicated in the recipe.  For the topping I then mixed togethter the 3/4c ketchup, 1/2 c brown sugar and T of Worcestershire sauce.  I spread about 3/4 on top and after 40 minutes coated the top with remaining.  It was a hit!!!

text:
I have made this before but I guess I never reviewed it. My review is form this time. I made it with 93% Ground Beef for less fat. I also cooked it in a meatloaf pan and i was surprised to see almost no fat underneath (i guess since it was so low in fat in general). Anyway, I added 1 heaping Tbs. of minced garlic to the mix and used Ritz instead of saltines. Since my pan allowed dripping to go underneath (not sit under the meat), I put the sauce on top (which I added some Worcestershire sauce too as recommended). It was done in 50 minutes. I love the meat with the sauce but my only issue is, as is, the bottom is plain meatloaf and the top had the glaze... so if I baked it NOT in a meatloaf pan, I would put half on the bottom and half on top of the glaze. Since I used the pan, next time I might mix half into the mix itself and then put the rest on top... but I do love it!
