text:
The only things I changed in this recipe was the amount of onion (a whole onion seemed a bit much to me), double the sauce, and instead of saltine crackers I used bread crumbs.  It was really out-of-this-world good!  I've never had much success with meatloaf - I can never get it done in the middle and then wind up baking it for too long as I try.  So for this one, I scooped a little sauce in the bottom of my muffin pans and put the meatloaf mixture in that to bake.  I was concerned about the grease not draining out, so I formed little "wells" in the middle of the meat and scooped the grease out when it was done.  It took about 30 minutes to bake; I took them out and put more sauce on top for the last few minutes. Everyone loved the result!

text:
This was a great recipe.  I read the other reviews and made a few small changes though...  I only had 1 1/4 lbs of turkey, so I changed the ingredient quantities to make 6 serving sizes instead of 8.  I didn't go down to 5 serving sizes because I added 2 shredded carrots and 2 chopped celery stalks and 1/4 cup of chopped onion.  I soaked the bread crumbs in the milk as suggested.  I only had plain bread crumbs, so I added 2 teaspoons of italian seasoning to the bread crumbs.  I also added a pinch of garlic powder.  I used shredded cheddar and monterey jack cheese because that's what I had.  And finally, I added 1 tbsp of brown sugar to the ketchup.  I only cooked to 160 degrees (which took almost an hour) and let it rest under foil to 165.  The meatloaf was flavorful and moist.  I will definitely make it again.

I have never made meatloaf before, so I wasn't quite sure what to expect.  Following the suggestions of others, I used 1/4 cup of each brown sugar and ketchup and added a splash of worcestershire sauce and used it as a glaze.  I used 1/4 cup of milk, doubled the ginger, and used crushed corn chips instead of crackers.  I also put in less salt and added a splash of soy sauce.  When the meatloaf came out, it looked fantastic and tasted very good.  I found it a bit mushy and there was too much onion for my taste.  I also found the sweetness of the glaze a little overpowering.  I think next time I make this, I'll use less glaze.  It was very good tasting and I found it nice that you can modify it to your own tastes.

Delicious comfort food!  My changes: added 1 t. minced garlic, 1/3 c. red onion, 1/3 c. green bell pepper, 1/3 c. canned mushrooms (drained), 2 green onions, 1 T. Worcestershire sauce, and 2 t. prepared mustard to meat mix; added 2 T. Worcestershire sauce to the glaze; used 1/4 – 1/2 c. milk in the meat mix and 1/4 c. of brown sugar in the glaze; used a little over 1/4 c. Italian bread crumbs and a little more than 1/2 c. rolled oats in place of cracker crumbs; put most of glaze on prior to cooking (on top of loaf), but basted meatloaf with remaining glaze 5 minutes before the end of cooking time.  My husband likes the glaze, so next time I will make some extra so that he can pour it over his meatloaf for use as extra sauce.  FYI: this meatloaf is great with ground beef only, but tastes just as good when 1/2 lb. ground turkey and 1 lb. ground beef are used---husband couldn’t tell the difference and neither could I!

This is a great meatloaf recipe. I added about 1/4 tsp of ground mustard to the meat mixture and next time I am going to add a finely chopped green pepper. Okay, my father is the master of meatloaf in our house, and when I made this, he said it was the best he had ever had!  So needless to say, it was excellent.  I, along with countless others, wondered what good the sauce would be on the bottom...so I formed my loaf and then mixed the brown sugar, ketchup and a dash of worchestershire, then spread over the top.  I put a few slices of bread on the side to soak up the grease, and voila!--the best meatloaf.  It's definately a keeper.

I made this last night for dinner and my family loved it!  My husband took what was left over to work for lunch today.  I didn't change any of the ingredients, I only changed how it was prepared.  I mixed the meatloaf as directed and instead of putting in a loaf pan, I placed it on a baking sheet and molded it into a loaf.  Then I combined the brown sugar and ketchup and poured in on top of the meat loaf.  It seemed to soak into the meatloaf a little more than placing it on the bottom.  I will be making this again!!

text:
I've made a few Meatloafs from this site.  This was one of the better ones we tried.  The big change I made while cooking was to cook 4 smaller loafs on a wire rack on top of a drip pan and not in a loaf pan.  All the drippings and grease were at the bottom of the pan.  We dressed the loafs with the ketchup/brown suger mixture twice during the cooking.  All and all, it turned out very well.  Hope this helps.

I don't know if anyone else makes mealoaf from gound pork but this meatloaf is perfect for pork. After reading many of the reviews, I decided to add a packet of onion soup mix and one tablespoon worcestirshire to the meat mixure and another tablespoon to the ketchup. I put the glaze on top. I don't use a loaf pan as i find meatloaf is much better if it's just shaped and cooked on a baking sheet. I can see why this recipe is so popular. It is fantastic.

text:
FEAR NOT THE UPSIDE-DOWNNESS  There is a trick to this recipe and that is FOLLOW IT. Use LEAN ground beef (I used 93%) and then the juices from the meat mix with the brown sugar and ketchup at the bottom to form the most delightful glaze/gravy. There wasn't even enough grease to congeal on the left overs in the fridge. It might be a tad sweet for some, but we loved it. So trust the recipe - do it as written.

text:
This meatloaf is very good, but a few tips: First, when the meatloaf is almost done, put on a baking sheet with the glazed portion on top.  Continue to bake until finished; this will give the top a very appealing look, and will remove it from the grease in the original baking pan.  Also, instead of using crackers, take some white bread slices, run them through your food proccessor (or chop until fine with a good knife on a cutting board) and replace crackers with the bread.  Otherwise, a very nice family dish.

text:
I made this recipe last night and loved it!  I omitted the eggs, because I suprisingly didn't have any.  Every meatloaf recipe has eggs in it, and the only difference I notice is that the loaf 'held together' a little better.  It didn't seem to fall apart as easily when serving it out of the loaf pan.  I personally liked this factor.  Also, I put the ketchup and brown sugar on the top, instead of the bottom and added it in the last 30 minutes of cooking.  The reason why is because I like to drain any grease from the loaf halfway through cooking and the thought of the grease combining with the ketchup and brown sugar at the bottom kind of grossed me out.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly as written--sauce on the bottom, ginger(I did only use 1/2 cup milk, though and had to sub cheez-its for the saltines)...and my family and I quite enjoyed it.  It is true if you put the brown sugar and ketchup on the bottom it doesn't really flavor or "stick" to the meatloaf, but that was the genius part of it to me.  Those who wanted it could spoon extra on their portions, those who didn't, well, problem solved.  Yes, it was a very sweet sauce, but I liked it, it was a nice change to what I'm used to.  I also liked the texture.  It was a nice firm meatloaf--I hate soft, mushy loaves.  My only critique may be that it could use a little extra flavor, maybe a squirt of ketchup and mustard and more pepper in the meat mixture, but all in all, a good recipe.

My husband said this was the best meatloaf he ever tasted (including his mom's)!  I did make some changes.  I changed the servings so that I could use 2 lbs of hamburger.  I added green pepper and fresh onion.  I used bread crumbs instead of crackers.  When I mixed the sauce, I doubled it and added some to the meatloaf mixture then poured the rest on top.  I halved the brown sugar instead of using the full amount.  I also added some hot sauce to the sauce mixture to add a little 'kick' to it.  After baking for a little over an hour, I broiled to give it a charmalized look and taste.  Next time I am going to make more sauce and put it on the top, in the meat mixture, and on the bottom.  After using the recipe off the onion soup mix box for years, I will never go back to that again!

text:
This meatloaf is really quite delicious. Though I did add more seasonings (worsteshire sauce,paprika,soy sauce) and I did use less milk and breadcrumbs instead of crackers. I omitted the ginger  I just didn't think it would work with the ground beef. I think that the brown sugar and ketchup, basically bbq sauce  but a perfectly measured one :) should go on top so it doesn't get lost in all the juices as the meatloaf cooks. I love garlic , so I add a few cloves into the meat. It does caramelize well and you won't get that ugly sticky burnt top if you use enough ketchup. This is the only way I do meatloaf now. You can change it up but the recipe itself is great!   YUMMY!

This is my favorite recipe for meatloaf.  I usually prepare as directed and divide in half to make two smaller loafs(perfect for my husband and I), except, I only cook them for 40 minutes rather than an hour as stated. After baking, I use my vacuum sealer to seal the other meatloaf.  Before I leave for work in the morning, I let the loaf thaw in the fridge and then as instructed by the vacuum sealer manufacturer, just re-heat by putting the whole pouch in a pot of water (do not boil) for about 20-minutes until heated throughout and you have a moist, delicious, home-cooked dinner on a busy work night!!

text:
Not horrible but my favorite by a long shot.  For one, other than the ginger, it doesn't have a lot of seasoning.  Also, the ketchup/brown sugar mix is just too sweet by itself.  I prefer to mix in some dry mustard for a bit of tang.  Also, as noted previously, putting the sugar and ketchup on the bottom has an ick factor for me.  What happened was it turns into watery, fat laden goo at the bottom.  Not that appetizing for me.  I prefer it on the top and will keep doing that from now one.  The loaf had a wierd texture that I can only attribute to the sauce on the bottom combined with it essentially boiled the meat.  Leftovers were not that appetizing.  I like to have leftover meatloaf sandwiches and this didn't fit the bill.

I've made it twice, just to make sure I didn't do something wrong the first time, and still wasn't overly impressed.  The texture is also a bit too wet for me.  It cooks in it's own grease, then the grease gets mixed in with the brown sugar & ketchup on the bottom, so very greasy. 

I would give it 3.5 stars if I could, but not quite good enough for 4 stars.

text:
Before I moved South, I thought there was only one kind of meatloaf--wrong. There is this kind with more of a sweet and sour sauce flavor, then a straight up ketchup kind. As far as the Southern Style meatloaf goes, this one is awesome. I do, though, prefer a little more ketchup flavor, and will modify it the next time I make it. I used seasoned breadcrumbs instead of crackers, reduced the brown sugar (thank goodness!), and added worstechire sauce to both the glaze and the meat. I will admit, it is delicious, and I will definitely make again.

My sister came to visit and we wanted comfort food so we thought, meatloaf! I found this recipe and was interested.  I love the basic premise but changed a few things.
1.I added half a green pepper and 2 cloves of garlic
2.no ginger!!!
3. added 1tsp soy sauce, 1tsp worcesteshire sauce.
4.half beef, half pork
I pureed the pepper, onion and garlic (remember family hates chunky veggies.
after reading other reviews, I used only a quarter of the brown sugar.  I ran out of ketchup so I had to mix cocktail sauce with it to put over the sugar.  I had to add about a half a cup of plain bread crumbs, the pureed veggies added moisture. It was awesome!!  got many rave reviews.  loved it, will use it again.

Outstanding!  I pretty much make the recipe as given with a few minor changes: I don't use meatloaf pans. I just form a loaf by hand in a baking pan & then slather (again with my hands) the loaf with the ketchup and brown sugar mix before throwing it into the oven. I also just keep a bag with cracker crumbs in it--you know, those bits and pieces of Cheez-Its or Ritz crackers that no one will eat--so I just use whatever's in there instead of saltines. The cheese crackers actually work well with this. This is the only meatloaf recipe I make now.

This recipe is amazing.  Only slight changes made all the difference. After I greased the pan, i put marinara and honey on the bottom, and saved the kectchup and brown sugar mix for the top only. I also used sweetended condensed can milk instead of regular milk, and used corn flake crumbs instead of crackers. I followed the recipe exactly and used 93% lean hamburger.  I basted the meatloaf every 10 minutes for the last 1/2 hour of baking time and it did leave a nice glaze on the top.  The only meatloaf I've made in the past was the one that contains oats in it, which I think is gross.
2012 Edit - Tried a grated pan with the brown sugar/catsup on top instead of bottom.  mmmmm Enough said!

I think the next time I make it, I'll put the brown sugar/catchup on top of the meatloaf instead of the bottom.  I'll also put it on a grated pan so the loaf is not floating in its own grease. 

In all, the flavor was wonderful and my family did enjoy this.  Thanks!

text:
a great tasting meatloaf from a non-lover of meatloaf.  Added some Lea & Perrins, Lawry's seasonsalt in place of regular salt, and Ritz cracker crumbs.  Kept the method of preparation the same because I was curious in preparing a meatloaf this way.  I waited for it to cool a bit and flipped it out onto a platter so the sauce would be on top.  The only thing I don't like about the sauce being on the bottom, is that it mixes with the grease from the beef(used ground chuck).  I will follow LadyJayPee's advice and next time drain off some of the dripping then place the brown sugar/ketchup mixture on top.  I did like the sweet/savory combo.  I didn't find it too loose, it stayed together in a rectangle and cut perfectly into slices.  DH is the meatloaf lover in the house and will enjoy.

I altered this quite a bit, and I am glad I did otherwise I don't think the meat itself would have had enough flavor.  I followed the reciped, but instead of saltines, I used 1 1/2 cups of crushed cheez-its. (you need more to thicken the loaf, otherwise it was a huge ball of mush) I added about 1/2 cup shredded chedder cheese.  I doubled the ginger, and lessened the brown sugar.  I think I should have halved the brown sugar and ketchup as it was WAY too sweet.  My two year old and I liked it, but my husband thought it was too sweet.  The meatloaf itself was yummy, flavorful and moist.

text:
Like most other reviewers, I cut the sugar in half.  I also used Heinz 57 instead of ketchup (because it was all I had in the fridge).  I used dried onion flakes instead of real onion and crushed ginger from a jar instead of dried (about 1/2 tsp jarred vs. 1/4 tsp dried).  Like other reviewers, I put most of the brown sugar glaze on the top of the meatloaf.  This was FANTASTIC.  We don't even like meatloaf.  My boyfriend bought a huge pack of ground beef, and I was desparate for a way to use it up before it went bad.  But we *both* loved this.  The leftovers didn't last long at all.  We would definitely make this again.  We were pleasantly surprised by this recipe!  Who knew we liked meatloaf?

No one in my family is a fan of meatloaf except for my twelve year old son. He complains  that i never make it so i searched for a new recipe because my old one was not up to  par. Everyone in my family agreed this is the best meatloaf they ever had and that they would't mind having it once a month.  I stuck to the recipe pretty much just added some adobo and crushed garlic, and green and red peppers that i sauteed in a little olive oil to the meat. I also put the brown sugar and ketchup on top of the loaf because i don't use a loaf pan, just shaped the meat into a loaf.

text:
To quote my dh "This is the best meatloaf I have ever had!" and I agree.  This will be the ONLY recipe I use for meatloaf from now on.  I followed the recipe with just these changes - I used 1# 95% lean gr. beef and 1# gr. pork loin - just cuz that's what I happened to have on hand.  Because of the extra meat, I increased the oatmeal by a scant 1/4c - I used oatmeal instead of bread based on other's recommendations- and did NOT reduce the milk.  I used seasoned salt instead of regular.  I adjusted my baking time to 40 minutes because my oven was set at 400 since baked potatoes were also on the menu.  This recipe is well-deserving of its high rating.  I'd give it a 10 if I could!!

This meatloaf is a kid pleaser.  However, I did make a few changes.  The milk makes the meat WAY too mushy, so I omitted that.  I also beat the eggs first before adding. The sauce is pretty sweet but that is what the kids like about it, I'm sure you could cut down the sugar and it would still be good.  Thanks for the recipe.

This recipe was fantastic. I left out the onions because the kids don't like them, but they LOVED this meatloaf. I got a "hands down, best EVER". Even the picky 7 year old loved it. My boyfriend liked it a lot, but he prefers traditional meatloaf. I prepared as the recipe called for except for the onions and I drizzled some brown sugar and ketchup on the top. Holy cow, this was fantastic! I made a slight change - I was feeding quite the horde (6 children and 3 adults) so I used 1 1/2lbs 93% lean beef and a 1lb roll of maple sausage. I put in a bunch of onion powder instead of onions (my kids hate onions, and can even detect cooked onions in food), otherwise I followed the recipe exactly, just adjusting quantities to make 1 1/2 recipes. My friend's kids all cleaned their plates and had seconds, and her daughters never eat all their food. Even my friend ate a big piece, and we usually have to fight to get her to eat much of anything. My husband was upset there wasn't more of it! So this was an all around hit with children and adults. I did make sure to let it sit for a few minutes after I took it out of the oven, then turned the loaves out on a platter so the glaze ended up on top and dripped down the sides. My friend was even dipping her tator tots in the ketchup/brown sugar glaze on the platter. I'll have to make this frequently!

text:
i made this recipe last night and it turned out okay.  it was different then just an ordinary meatloaf recipe because of the brown sugar and ketchup, but without that you just have an ordinary meatloaf.  i did as other users suggested and reduced the amount of brown sugar.  i took a 1/4 cup of it and mixed it in with the ketchup and put most of that on the bottom of my pan, then i sprinkled just a little bit more brown sugar on top of the mixture and put my meatloaf on top.  i saved a couple tablespoons of the ketchup/brown sugar mix and put it on top of the meatloaf also.  i found out that mine needed to be cooked a little over an hour.  it turned out to be good.  the brown sugar and ketchup is what makes it not ordinary, you could use that on your own meatloaf recipe if you wanted.  thanks for the recipe, will use it in the future.

This is absolutely the BEST meatloaf I've ever had! My hubby hates meatloaf, and even he loved this recipe! Like other reviewers, I only used 1/3 cup of brown sugar. I mixed it together w/ the Ketchup and with a little Worcestershire sauce. I put some on the bottom of the meatloaf and I put the rest on top before putting it in the oven. The whole thing cooked perfectly in an hour and 10 minutes.  I used 80% lean ground beef rather than 90% lean, but it was fine. I just drained out the grease a couple of times during cooking.  The texture of the meatloaf was perfect, and I had absolutely no mess at all unlike some previous posts. It really is a yummy recipe! Thanks Starbuck! This one is a keeper!! Ally
